SummaryOfEvents: Capri, a Maltese registered capsize bulk carrier arrived at Dampier anchorage, Australia on 22 December 2017. The vessel was scheduled to load 164,000 tonnes of iron ore for China. On 24 December, while at anchor, the vessel deballasted ballast tanks nos. 1 and 4 (port and starboard) in order to reduce the number of ballast tanks which she would have to deballast, once alongside when loading operations would start. The vessel then berthed in the evening of 25 December and since loading had not started, the chief mate opted to strip the ballast tanks that had been emptied during the day before. On completion at 2330, he advised the engine-room to line up the ballast system so that deballasting could take place when loading started. Loading started at 0229 on 26 December and the chief mate instructed the engine-room to prepare for deballasting operations; this required the starting of an additional generator. The chief mate then opened the remote suction valves to ballast tanks nos. 2 port and starboard. Soon afterwards, a loud bang was heard and the vessel blacked out. Power was eventually restored and the crew discovered a spray of water coming from the ballast pump suction strainer cover that was reaching the electrical distribution panel located close to the strainer. Water was steadily rising in the engine-room bilges. Despite isolating the ballast system, about 1,100 tonnes of sea water flooded into the engine-room. The ballast pump strainer cover and a ballast valve appeared to have been damaged when valves to ballast tanks port & starboard nos. 2 were opened. A number of electrical motors, switchboards, cabling, as well as the disabling of the main engine was directly attributed to the ingress of seawater into the engine-room. The vessel was subsequently towed to Singapore where the vessels equipment was overhauled and refitted.

El día lunes 25 de diciembre del 2017 se produjo el siniestro de la Nave Mayor "JACAF" en transito por Canal Tenglo, la que perdió el poder de ambos motores propulsores quedando sin maquinas .
Producto de la falla de maquinas , la nave tuvo contacto con el pilote luminoso 411 del Canal Tenglo , el cual es parte de la señaletica marítima de la zona de navegación descrita.
No se registraron victimas fatales, lesionados, o desaparecidos.
No se registraron daños en el medio ambiente .
La nave solo registro daños menores de pintura en el área donde se produjo el contacto con el pilote luminoso.
La falla de máquinas fue producida por falta de alimentación del sistema de combustible al encontrarse las válvulas del circuito cerradas.
Las pruebas posteriores efectuadas por el Inspector de Máquinas de la Comisión Local de Inspección de Naves de Puerto Montt indicaron que la nave no presentaba falla en el sistema de maquina principal y en el sistema de gobierno , efectuándose prueba de maquinas y gobierno sin observaciones.
La nave quedo operativa sin limitaciones de navegación.

On or about 1115H Local Time (LT) of 21 December 2017, M/V MERCRAFT 3 capsize and sank between the vicinity of Dinahican Point and Agta Point at the position of LAT: 14°42'N, LONG: 121°47'E while navigating at Lamon Bay towards Polillo Islands.
By way of background, M/V MERCRAFT 3 was originally scheduled to depart at around 0615H OF 21 December 2017, based on her approved sailing schedules reflected on her Certificate of Public Convenience (CPC),  but was delayed due to the weather condition brought by the northeast monsoon (Amihan). Accordingly, no Public Storm Warning Signals (PSWS) had been raised in the area during the time of the casualty. Nevertheless, based on Gale Warning No. 59 issued by the Philippine Atmospheric, Geophysical and Astronomical Services Administration (PAGASA) on 5:00 am of 21 December 2017,  the eastern seaboards of southern Luzon including the island Polillo are expected to experience strong to gale force winds with wave height measuring 2.8 to 4.5 meters. 
At around 0913H of 21 December 2017, M/V MERCRAFT 3 finally departed the port of Ungos, Real Quezon under voyage No. 01 bound to Polillo Port carrying 251 passengers and seven (7) crew compliments. The 206.27 tons Fiberglass Reinforced Plastic (FRP) hulled catamaran passenger vessel was cruising at a speed of 10.5 knots due to the prevailing sea conditions at the time.

At around 0955H, while plying between the area of Dinahican Pt. and Agta Pt. in the area called “Kasiligan”, MV MERCRAFT 3 was battered by steep waves and subsequently hit a hard floating object on her starboard bow.The Master of the vessel immediately reduced their speed to 4 knots in order to assess the situation. Consequently, due to the reduction of the vessel’s propulsion, MV MERCRAFT 3 failed to compensate with the prevailing wave motion at the time, thus positioning her bow under the bottom of the trough instead on top of the crest of the wave. MV MERCRAFT 3 was slammed by second steep breaking waves on her forward section displacing the crates of deck cargoes and prompting it to collided with the stud bolt lock securing the fore peak hatches (P/S). Thus, prompting the ingress on water on her main deck. Furthermore, several of the medical oxygen cylinders stowed on the fore section was disentangled from its securing attachments.

As a result of the incident, the hatch covers were dislodged and sea water started to enter the forepeak compartments (P/S) when the flair of the bow is acted upon and pushed downward whileMV MERCRAFT 3 is subjected to heavy pitching and surging motion.

Consequently, MV MERCRAFT 3 develops an initial list of 5° to starboard, while being continuous battered by 3-5 meter breaking waveson her port. The Master tries to maneuver the vessel to hard port in order to shelter her broadside from windward direction and irregular waves.In addition, portable submersible pumps were used by the crew to pump out sea water on the fore peak compartments, but was ineffective due to the inflow of sea water while being subjected to pitching and surging motion.
Accordingly, the FRP Catamaran passenger vessel was having difficulty in maneuvering to port due to the drag produced by her flooded starboard forward compartment and considerable windage at her port side. To prevent further ingress of water, the Master tried to maneuver the vessel to astern. However, it was discern that the hatch covers at the aft manhole access (P/S) leading to engine room no. 2 was left open. This incited sea water to enter and flood engine room no. 2 every time the vessel maneuvers astern.

The vessel was afloat for almost one (1) hour trying to stabilize her position while awaiting rescue. On or about 1100H the Master gave the command to abandon ship, every passenger was ushered by the crew to wear their life jacket and jump in the water. Fifteen (15) minutes after the evacuation, MV MERCRAFT 3 capsizeson her starboard side and sank at approximately 7 NM off Dinahican Pt.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Total loss of the ship

During the early morning hours of 8 December 2018 while Vision of the Seas was on passage from Cozumel, Mexico to Galveston Texas a crew member was reported missing by his supervisor. The missing person was identified as a 24 year old male Mauritian citizen who had joined the ship on 30 November 2017 as a Pool Cleaner. Although he reported for work at 0500 hours on 8 December, he did not show up for a safety training session scheduled at 0930 hours. His absence was not investigated at this time. The fact that he was missing was only noted following his failure to report back to work after the training was completed. 

Announcements were made over the ship's PA system in crew areas and then in all areas of the ship without result. At this stage all relevant notifications were made including the ship operators and United States Coast Guard Galveston. A ship search was initiated which failed to locate the crew member. Reviews of CCTV footage reveled the crew member had climbed over the stern rail between the life rafts mounted aft. At this location the deck below extends further aft and the missing crewman is seen climbing back over the rail and walking to the port aft quarter where there is direct access to the sea below. 

At 0514 hours a shadow on CCTV indicates the crew member had jumped overboard. The cameras that cover the decks in this area where he would appear if he walked away from the blind spot do not show him onboard after 0514 hours. He was seen to be carrying a red bucket which was later found against the handrail aft on the port quarter.

SummaryOfEvents: Santa Maria was alongside a vessel in Bunkering Area 3 West, about 12 nautical miles East by North from Maltas Grand Harbour. The bosun and another crew member were tasked with the mooring operation on the forecastle deck. At one point in time, the bosun let go of the windlass control lever and left it in the full heaving position, with the attempt to put a rope stopper on the mooring line once it was brought under full tension. In reaching for the stopper, the bosun passed over the mooring rope, when he lost his balance, and tripped over the mooring rope, in close proximity of the warping drum. As a result of the fall the bosuns legs got trapped between the incoming rope as well as the slack rope coming off the warping drum being handled by the deck rating and the rotating warping drum. The bosun was immediately assisted by other crew members and was eventually air lifted from the vessel and transferred to a local hospital. The immediate cause of the accident was considered to be the crew members fall in close proximity to the rotating warping drum

At about 1415 UTC1 on 20 November 2017, the single-handed creel boat Varuna was found aground and unmanned on Eilean nan Naomh, a small island to the west of Camusterrach.
Varuna had left its mooring earlier in the day and had been seen working creel strings to the west of Applecross Bay. Radar data from a local shore installation indicated that Varuna left its fishing grounds at 1332 and then headed back towards its mooring in Poll Creadha.
In the aftermath of the accident, an extensive sea, land and air search failed to locate the boat owner/skipper, who had been the only person on board. However, almost 3 weeks after the accident, his body was found ashore in Staffin Bay on the Isle of Skye.
It is likely that the owner/skipper, who did not routinely wear a lifejacket or other buoyancy aid, fell overboard during Varuna’s return passage to Poll Creadha.

In the evening of 18 November 2017, the Maltese registered bulk carrier Eleni M departed Porto Marghera in Italy, bound for Alexandria in Egypt with a cargo consisting of iron. After departure, the crew members on deck began to tidy up in preparation for sea passage. On the aft deck, the mooring lines that had been used while the ship was in port were being secured on the two mooring winches. During the final stage of the securing process, the last mooring line on the port side winch, the AB who arranged the mooring line on the winch drum assisted by one deck cadet, was caught in the winch and dragged into the limited clearance between the reeled-in mooring rope on the winch drum and the deck underneath. This happened within only a few seconds, while the assisting cadet had approached the AB who was operating the winch to convey the message to stop reeling in. The AB got crushed between the deck and the mooring rope and consequently he was severely injured. He was later pronounced dead by a medical doctor on board a Coast Guard vessel, which had come to assist and evacuate the casualty. The safety investigation of the fatal accident revealed that in order to perform the task of stowing the mooring ropes on the winch drum, the crew members had to engage physically with the ropes while the winch was rotating, to stow it properly and make room for all of the rope. The close proximity to the rotating winch and physical interaction made it possible to get caught. Furthermore, communication among the crew members easily became ineffective due to the setup of the mooring arrangement and loud noises on the aft mooring deck.

On Thursday 16 November 2017, one of the crew member fell overboard from the wellboat ysund in Skudenesfjorden south of Karmsundet. The accident occurred when the ships ordinary seaman went over the main deck to assist the apprentice who had suffered an injury to his foot that got caught by the door when entering the engine room. The ordinary seaman most likely fell overboard as a wave washed over the deck. The crew member was found and rescued with the MOB-boat, and transported to Haukeland Hospital by helicopter. The person was declared deceased at the hospital the following day. ysund has a typical wellboat design with a low freeboard in loaded condition, which often leads to water on the main deck in rough sea. ysund was equipped with an elevated walkway (storm bridge) over the main deck, but about of this consisted of the vessel's gangway. The storm bridge did not meet the requirements of the Load Line Convention, and the crew did not experience it as safe to use in rough sea conditions. The Norwegian Maritime Directorate has informed that they are preparing a circular on this issue and that they will have more focus on enforcing the relevant provision. ysund has received an instruction to improve the storm bridge to comply with regulatory requirements. The investigation has shown that the wellboat company and the ship management had not implemented measures to reduce the risk for crew being located on the main deck in rough sea. There were no established procedures or guidelines for the crew being on the main deck, nor the use of communication equipment or personal safety equipment when staying or working on the main deck. Furthermore, there were several actions during the rescue operation that were not performed according to the ship procedures. This might be because the crew was not well trained in carrying out realistic MOB-boat exercises. The Norwegian accident investigation board issues two safety recommendations to the wellboat company as a result of the investigation.

SummaryOfEvents: On 09 November 2017 Carnival Inspiration was traveling enroute to Long Beach California when a report was made to the ship's Staff Chief Engineer that a crew member did not report for duty and was unable to be located. The crewman concerned was identified a 33 year old Indian national who served as a Wiper onboard. Repeated announcements for the crew member to report were made via the ship's public address system but with no response. A search of the crew accommodation was also carried out indicating one crew member missing therefore confirming his disappearance. Man overboard recordings were reviewed and that review determined no sightings of a possible man overboard incident. The vessel's command elected not to turn around to undertake a man overboard search as the last sighting of the Wiper aboard on CCTV had been 16 hours earlier. Man overboard cameras did not indicate a potential fall overboard and at an average speed of 6 knots the vessel had traveled 98 miles from the location of that last confirmed sighting. The vessel was all fast at Long beach terminal at 0545 hours on 10 November. At 1030 hours a comprehensive vessel search was completed while the ship was moored alongside. The missing crew member was not located and his whereabouts remain unknown.

On 5 November 2017 at about 0730H, while the Singapore registered container vessel Wan Hai 212 was alongside the port of Tai Chung, Taiwan, China, one of its crew sustained fatal injuries after falling from a height of about 14 metres during cargo operations.
Witness account indicated that while walking on the catwalk, which was cluttered with loose lashing gears, the crew slipped, lost his balance and fell backward into the open cargo hold which did not have any safety railings or safeguards.
The crew was attended to by shore medical personnel and conveyed to the hospital. The crew succumbed to his injuries.

The investigation revealed that the accident was a result of inadequate risk control measures put in place to prevent a fall into an open cargo hold, especially in a walkway which was wet, narrow and cluttered with loose lashing gears.

As the vessel approached the port under pilotage, she was navigated on the wrong side of a breakwater, resulting in her grounding with the port side to the rocky breakwater (see Figure 1) at a position, 64°01'347 N and 022°33'111 W.

The vessel suffered substantial damage with the result of considerable leakage. The vessel was towed from the grounding site six days later and subsequently towed to Port of Keflavik where she was prepared for further transport. 

Fjordvik was towed to Port of Hafnarfjordur where  she was docked in a floating dock. Upon examination, she was deemed unfit for repair and subsequently transported by heavy load carrier to Belgium where her demolition took place. 

At the request of the Bahamas Maritime Investigations Department, the incident is being investigated by the Icelandic Transportation Safety Board (ITSB).

SummaryOfEvents: At about 2311 (UTC+2) on 10 October 2017, a Netherlands registered general cargo vessel ran aground on the UK coastline. There were no resulting injuries or pollution. The vessel's bow shell plating and frames were damaged by the grounding, which resulted in flooding of the bow thruster space and forward voids. At 0022 the following day, the vessel was refloated without assistance and, after inspection the vessel proceeded for temporary repairs. The investigation found that the cargo vessel grounded because no action had been taken to correct a deviation from the ships planned track. The master, who was the sole watchkeeper, had left the bridge, and the bridge navigational watch alarm system, which could have alerted the chief officer to the fact that the bridge was unmanned, had been switched off. The master had been consuming alcohol before taking over the watch, contrary to the companys policy. The chief officer had previously been concerned over the masters regular excessive consumption of alcohol, but at the watch handover had been satisfied that the master was fit to take the watch.

During a voyage from Visby to Oskarshamn, the vessel ATLANTIC ran aground just south of Oskarshamn. The master, who was alone on the bridge at the time and had the Bridge Navigational Watch Alarm System (BNWAS) turned off, has stated that he fell asleep just after he made the turn north of land towards Oskarshamn. The information is supported by the vessels AIS track, which shows that no course corrections were made following the turn. After the vessel ran aground, both of the nautical officers were arrested by the police and taken ashore, as a result of which the vessel was without a nautical officer in charge for some time. The cause of the accident was deficiencies in the monitoring of the navigation due to the master falling asleep during his watch on the bridge and because there was no lookout. Contributing causes to the master falling asleep included an accumulated sleep deficit and the fact that he was working on a two-watch system, which had likely contributed to the sleep deficit over a longer period of time. The master was under the influence of alcohol at the time of the grounding. Furthermore, the Bridge Navigation Watch Alarm System (BNWAS) had been turned off, which could have prevented the master from falling asleep or at least alerted the rest of the crew. A contributing cause to the lack of a lookout on the bridge was the vessels limited crew, in combination with the shipping companys ISM providing insufficient support to the master, which had not been noted in the classification reviews of the shipping company and the vessel.

On the evening of 26 August 2017, at about 2300H, the supply vessel Coastlink 8 came alongside the westbound chemical tanker, Chem Antares to provide a scheduled transfer of ship’s stores while the latter was underway in the vicinity of Raffles Shoal.

Soon after the Coastlink 8 came alongside, and to facilitate the lifting of stores from the Coastlink 8, the mid-ship crane of the Chem Antares was lowered. When the crane hook had been attached to the cargo net containing the first lift, the bow of the Coastlink 8 began to veer starboard and it began moving away from the transit vessel. 

In an attempt to guide the lift back on to the cargo deck for aborting the operation, the Master of Coastlink 8 handed the steering control of the vessel to another crew member and went out of the wheelhouse. While assisting to adjust the cargo net to its original position, the cargo net got lifted off the main deck and swung towards the transit vessel.

The Master although warned by the other crew to stay clear was hit by the swinging lift and thrown overboard. A search and rescue operation was launched but his body could not be found, until four days later, and eventually recovered by Singapore Police Coast Guard at the sea off Marina South Pier.

The TSIB classified the occurrence as a Very Serious Marine Casualty and launched an investigation.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Ship remains fit to proceed

- The LEO TRIO was engaged on a voyage from Taranto, Italy to Kaolack, Senegal, covering a total of approximately 2,930 nautical miles.
- The vessel was loaded with a total of two thousand three hundred and fifty (2,350.00) tonnes of cement in big bags.
- On the 20th August 2017 the vessel was deviated from her original voyage to the Port of Ceuta, Spain to take bunkers.
- The vessel departed from Ceuta on the 21st August 2017  early morning destined to the Senegal.
- Several hours after departure from the Port of Ceuta a stowaway was discovered onboard.
- The stowaway was said to be offered with food and drink and managers advised the Captain to continue with the voyage to the Port of Kaolack, Senegal from    where the P&I would take care of him.
- On the 22nd August 2017 from 00.0 to 03,28 hrs the vessel was underway with an average speed of 9.0 knots and a constant course of 237º-238º
- Suddenly within minutes the vessel experiences a diminution on the speed down to 6.4 knots and a sudden alteration on the course of almost 90º from the original course to 325º 
- Right after this even, the vessel goes back to original speed and course.
- Immediately after the Moroccan authorities receive a distress call from a fishing boat in the area of the above event.
- Within 24 hours the Moroccan navy intercepted the LEO TRIO asking them to deviate course towards Agadir, Morocco.
- The LEO TRIO was allegedly accused of being involved in a collision with a fishing boat which caused  the death of two crew members.
- Crew statements gathered during the interviews onboard where not in line with the evidence found from several sources.
- This report will try to analyse the different contributing factors leading to this accident as well as the possible human factor related to its cause. Analysis of accident management by the crew and the difficulties encountered will be also taken care of in this report.

6th August 2017, vessel departed her load port in Norway bound for Thailand with a full cargo of ammonium nitrate based fertilisers, within a few days when opening #4 cargo hold hatch cover drains, small collections of water, and a barely discernible “light dust” were observed.
This deteriorated and the cargo manufacturers were contacted for advice. They advised that a cargo thermal decomposition was most likely occurring. With rising temperatures and increasing quantities of toxic gas and despite attempts at cooling the decomposition front with water, the situation worsened.
Prevailing still weather conditions, danger to personnel caused by the toxic gas cloud and a rapid deterioration of the on-board situation ultimately resulted in the Master ordering evacuation from the vessel. Spain MRCC responded using two search and rescue helicopters and successfully landed the crew and cargo surveyor in Las Palmas.
The vessel, being no longer under command or power, drifted (under MRCC supervision) in a South-Westerly direction further away from land whilst the decomposition continued.  The vessel was towed to Puerto Motril for discharge and repair assessments but was ultimately declared a constructive total loss since cost-effective repairs could not be carried out.

The vessel arrived at Marsaxlokk Oil Tanking Terminal loaded with two parcels of cargo. Following the successful completion of the cargo operation, the crew members started the ballasting of the vessel since her next trip to Spain was a ballast voyage. Ballasting in the forepeak tank started under the supervision of the second mate.

About an hour later, at about 1300, a high bilge level alarm in the bow thruster compartment sounded on the vessel s Alarm Monitoring System. The bosun proceeded forward to investigate. He immediately noticed water escaping from the forepeak tank s manhole, reaching the bow thruster entrance, flowing over the sill plate and cascading on the bow thruster motor. Consequently, one of the bilge alarms in the bow thruster compartment triggered the high level alarm.

Aware of possible issues with the bow thruster motor, the chief engineer instructed the electrician to inspect the motor for any water damages. Prior to the commencement of the work, three safety documents were signed. The bow thruster electrical supply to the ventilation fan and the bow thruster motor was isolated. As part of the cleaning process, the electrician sprayed the motor with an electrical cleaner using a pneumatic spray gun. He then proceeded to the messroom and returned to the bow thruster compartment at around 1600. About 20 minute later, the bosun went to check on the electrician and found him unconscious, lying over the bow thruster tunnel.

Crew members were mustered and attempts made to lift the electrician from the bow thruster compartment. Eventually, shore assistance was requested and personnel from the local Civil Protection Department lifted the electrician to the open space on the forecastle deck. However, he was pronounced dead on board.

SOLASStatus: FV Mako: Non-SOLAS, GLASGOW EXPRESS: SOLAS
SummaryOfEvents:
What happened
At 2000 on 12 August 2017, the fishing vessel Mako departed San Remo, Victoria, bound for fishing grounds about 3 hours away. Once clear of Cape Woolamai, Mako maintained a steady course (210°) and speed to the south-west. At the same time, the container ship Glasgow Express was passing Cape Liptrap heading north-west. The ship was bound for Melbourne, Victoria, and was maintaining a steady course (299°) and speed. From about 2030 the vessels were on a collision course.
No avoiding action was taken by either vessel and, at about 2246, they collided.

What the ATSB found
The ATSB found that a proper lookout by ‘all available means’ was not being maintained on either vessel. 
Glasgow Express’s bridge team saw and monitored Mako visually from about 2200. However, a full appraisal of the situation using other instruments or means available on the bridge (such as radar) was not done. As a consequence, the situation was misinterpreted and the risk of collision was not identified. Therefore, no avoiding action was taken.
Prior to handing over the watch at 2230, Mako’s watchkeeper identified Glasgow Express by radar and visually. However, the information was misinterpreted and it was concluded that the Glasgow Express was passing clear, ahead of the fishing boat, and no avoiding action was taken. Then, after taking the watch, Mako’s second watchkeeper did not see the Glasgow Express until moments before the collision. 
In addition, Mako was under way with all external lights on. This made the vessel more easily seen, but reduced the ability for Glasgow Express’s bridge team to accurately visually appraise the situation. The bright lights also reduced Mako’s watchkeeper’s night vision and ability to distinguish features beyond the glare of the lights.
The ATSB also noted that Mako, similar to other fishing vessels of this design, had a large fishing net winch drum mounted on deck forward of the wheelhouse. This winch drum restricts forward vision and may limit the ability to maintain a proper lookout unless accounted for in on-board procedures and training.

What's been done as a result
Glasgow Express’s operator undertook a fleet-wide information and education program which outlined the incident and emphasised the need to use all available means to maintain safe navigation in accordance with the collision regulations.

Safety message
The ATSB continues to see collisions between trading ships and small vessels. A common contributing factor has been the failure to use all available means to accurately appraise a situation and the risk of collision. 
The ATSB reinforces to masters, owners, operators and skippers of all vessels the importance of a proper lookout by all available means including radar. Proper use of radar equipment including long range scanning and radar plotting allows for early detection, assessment and warning of vessels posing a risk of collision. This allows the watchkeeper sufficient time to take early and considered action to avoid collision in accordance with the International regulations for preventing collisions at sea, 1972 (as amended) (COLREGs).

At about 0955 on 12 August 2017, the Finnish-flagged FINNSKY, sailing inbound on the River Warnow, collided with the outbound German steam icebreaker STETTIN (a traditional vessel) at buoy 43/SM2. The FINNSKY had turned on the turning basin (position in the fairway for turning) and sailed astern on the western side of the fairway to Berth 60. The STETTIN was also sailing on the western side of the fairway and attempted to pass the oncoming FINNSKY on her port side. This manoeuvre was not discussed with the ship's command of the FINNSKY. A course alteration to port by the STETTIN with hard-over rudder was ultimately no longer sufficient to prevent the two vessels from colliding. During the collision, the starboard side of the STETTIN crashed into the FINNSKY's aft deflector (the so-called ducktail). The STETTIN suffered a gash above the waterline of about 2 m in length and 30 cm in height level with the boiler room. The FINNSKY's ducktail at the stern was slightly deformed on the port side and had a hole of 15 cm in length and 3 cm in height. There were ten casualties on board the STETTIN. No pollutants escaped.

On or about 1825LT of 27 July 2017, LCT Blue Hawk 88 ran aground onto the rocky shores of Brgy. Ipag, Mariveles, Bataanat the position of LAT: 14-25.17N, LONG: 120-27.25while on a course heading at 317°.
LCT Blue Hawk 88 departed the port of Bogo, Cebu on 1526 LT of 24 July 2017, under full ballast condition and no cargo onboard. Her draft condition prior to departure consists of FWD: 0.80 M: 1.80 AFT: 2.80.
Initially, The 1,857 GT steel hulled deck loading barge was on her intended course to Manila under voyage No. 186when she was advised by the charterer to change her course headingtowards Subic for possible loading operation. While on passage in the vicinity of Fortune Island, LCT Blue Hawk 88 began to alter her course heading from 348° to 350°near La Monja Island.
Accordingly, whilston passagenear La Monja Island (LAT. 14°22.5’N, LONG. 120°27.8’E),LCT Blue Hawk 88 began to experience moderate to heavy weather in the area and was intensely battered by huge waves, swells and heavy rains coming towards her port bow. 
At around 1630 LT of 27 July 2017, after reaching her next way point, she set her course to 317° at Napo Pt., a sudden strong gale with Beufort Scale 8/9, approximately 41-47 knots with strong winds coming from the westerly direction lashes towards LCT Blue Hawk 88. The Master of the vessel ordered to maneuver the vessel leeward away from the waves and near the shorein order to shelter the vessel from windward direction and irregular waves. 
Consequently, due to the south east direction of the gale, the weather created a lee shore prompting any vessel with low maneuverability to increase her leeway towards the shore.

Conversely, while on hard port rudder and full ahead engine, LCT Blue Hawk 88 began to drift broadside to starboard towards the rocky shores. With the wind and waves veering on her port side, the Master ordered the crew to drop her starboard anchor in order to positionher bow towards the sea.  LCT Blue Hawk 88 began to swing her stern counter clockwise, placing her bow towards the sea and her stern in the direction of the reefs.  However, the 83 meter cargo vessel started to drag her anchor and continue to drift astern towards the rocky shores of Brgy. Ipag, Mariveles, Bataan. 

At around 1825 LT of 27 July 2017, a sudden loud clank from the propeller was followed by a strong vibration from the stern was experienced by the crew indicating that the vessel hadstranded on the rocky portions of the reef. Thereafter, thevessel quickly turns to port along with her starboard anchor being drag parallel to the shore.
The Master immediately ordered to stop all engines as sea water started to enter and flood the engine room. The Mastered ordered all the crew to muster at the bridge while the vessel was continuously being pounded by strong waves on her starboard quarter. The crew immediately call for rescue and informed the company of the occurrence. All of the crew onboard manages to make it safely to shore the following day and medical assistance was rendered by the local rescue unit of Mariveles. 
The vessel remained aground for almost 2 days and, due to adverse weather conditions, she was pounded heavily onto the rocky foreshore. This caused material damage to her hull and breaching of the double bottom structure. On the 29th of July 2017, LCT Blue Hawk 88 broke in half with stress fractures emanating on her midship, the vessel was then declared a total loss by the owner and was consequently coordinating with the Insurance for wreck removal by a registered Salvor Company. There were no reported oil spill or fatalities involved in the incident.
LCT Blue Hawk 88 under Official Number CEB1008843 is owned by MARINEBEST SHIPPING SERVICES & MANAGEMENT, INC. under Ship management by PHILWINNER MARINE SERVICES, INC. and chartered by ABL MARINE SVCS.

The RN MURMANSK is a Cyprus flagged, 2009 built, oil and chemical tanker managed by SCF Management Services.The Chief Engineer disappeared while the ship was en route from the port of Arkhangelsk, Russia to the port of Isle of Grain, UK on 14th July 2017. The position of the ship when the crew members realized that the Chief Engineer was missing was Lat: 6504.0N Long: 00613.8E. The vessel was sailing on international waters west of the coast of Norway southbound to the United Kingdom.At the moment it was realized that the Chief Engineer was missing, the crew searched thoroughly the ship without any success. At the same time the Master gave command for the ship to change course and commence the Man Overboard Emergency procedures. After a fruitless search mission for more than 5 hours the vessel received orders to cancel the search and rescue mission and resume its original course.The body of the Chief Engineer was never found and he is presumed disappeared.Conclusion(s)There were no witnesses to the disappearance. There is no evidence that it was intentional.The investigation found that the condition of the structure, machinery and equipment of the vessel was satisfactory. It also showed that it was very difficult for someone to fall by accident overboard.Therefore, it is considered that in the absence of maritime safety related evidence, the Chief Engineers disappearance is not related to maritime safety.

On Wednesday, 12 July 2017, an engineer was subjected to a serious occupational accident on board the fishing vessel MS Fuglyfjord. The person was wedged in between the vessel's winch (triplex) and the wheelhouse bulkhead, during hauling of the fishing gear. A railing behind the triplex would have impeded access to the danger area. The railing was a part of the initial construction drawings, but not delivered. Neither the designer, the shipyard, the shipping company nor the authorities revealed the missing railing and signage in the area between the seine tube and wheelhouse bulkheads, during construction or at the completion of the vessel. Subsequent regulatory checks after the vessel came into operation took place alongside a quay, and did not capture the missing railing and associated danger area. Challenges of the lines being spun during hauling occurred after the vessel came into fishing. The crew established a practice for work in this danger zone where the skipper and the person overseeing the lines had visual and oral communication. Interference from one of the vessel's VHF radios caused the skipper to leave the manoeuvring position, thus losing the visual control of the engineer. A possible misunderstanding in the communication led to the skipper starting the hauling process without necessary visual control restored. The company's safety management system prior to the accident was considered deficient in documented risk assessments, measures and work instructions. After the accident, the company established several physical barriers and improved safety routines. The investigation has shown that the current regulations for the construction of vessels place few requirements on possible danger zones in the operation of fishing gear, and the authorities consider to a lesser extent operational safety at this stage. In previous investigations, the AIBN has also pointed out that it is crucial that work processes are evaluated during the design phase. The company's expectations to the participants in the design and construction phase were unclarified regarding their opportunities for influencing operational safety. The AIBN sees the importance of an extensive collaboration between vessel owners, designers and construction yards focusing on operational issues in the upcoming operational phase. The Accident Investigation Board Norway does not issue any safety recommendations after the investigation.

At 0055 on 12 July 2017, the Maltese registered container ship Kea Trader ran aground and stranded in position 22 02.28' S 168 38.25' E (Recif Durand) in the Pacific Ocean.  At the time, the vessel was on a passage from Papeete, Tahiti to Noumea, New Caledonia.
Kea Trader was using electronic chart display and information system (ECDIS) as the primary means of navigation and there were no paper charts on board.  The officer of the watch (OOW) was monitoring a route displayed on the ECDIS.  The zone of confidence (ZOC) of the electronic navigation chart (ENC) was D and displayed a caution symbol and textual message  [t]his chart cannot be accurately referred to WGS 84 datum; see caution message .
A salvage company was contracted by the managers to salve the vessel and to prevent marine pollution.  The salvors reported water ingress in the double bottom tanks, duct keel and cargo holds.  Containers in the lower tiers of the hold were flooded and fuel oil was detected in one of the cargo hold.  Pounded repetitively by heavy swell,
Kea Trader s engine-room bulkhead failed on 23 July.  No oil pollution was reportedly observed in the sea. The vessel was declared a constructive total loss on 28 September.
On 12 November, the vessel was again struck by heavy weather, fracturing the hull in way of frame 92. Consequently, all personnel were evacuated from the vessel. On 04 December, Kea Trader broke her back approximately in the same position.

During transit voyage from Pula to Venice, while the ship was proceeding at cruising speed, high temperature shutdowns activated on both engines.
Following investigation by crew for root cause, it was evident that this was due to fouling of sea chest suctions which did not allow the sea water to cool the FW and the main engines stopped of FW coolant high temperature.
PS and SS sea chests were found completely blocked of sea grass. Sea grass was removed, filters were cleaned and the coolant additionally cooled by FW.
Passengers, crew and company were informed of situation.
After cooling down, both engines were started and tested.
Order was received to proceed back to Pula were the passengers were disembarked and sea trial made with DNV surveyor and PSC representatives. The ship performed satisfactory. There were no any damages on the ship’s equipment.

At 0304:401 on 1 July 2017, two Hong Kong registered vessels, a large bulk carrier and an oil tanker, collided in a traffic lane of a traffic separation scheme. Both vessels were damaged in the collision but were able to proceed to nearby ports for damage assessment. The accident did not result in any injuries or pollution.

The safety investigation identified that a VHF radio conversation between the vessels had resulted in the two bridge teams holding conflicting views as to what had been agreed regarding the large bulk carrier overtaking the oil tanker. Subsequently, the oil tanker’s bridge team did not check for sea room astern before altering course, leading to a close quarter situation between the two vessels. The oil tanker’s master had been present on the bridge for over 14 hours and was probably suffering from fatigue, which was likely to have had an adverse effect on his decision making.

On 28 June 2017,At 0500 on 28 June 2017, Freyja berthed at Gunnhildevagen Terminal, Flor in Norway. By mid-day, she was ready to sail for Svelgen, a coastal passage of about 25 nautical miles.

At about 1250, the second mate arrived on the bridge and made his way to the chartroom to write the logbook. At the time, the master had the con. Approximately one minute later, Freyja was in the open water segment of the voyage, approaching waypoint no. 3. The next course to steer was 316 degrees. The course was altered to starboard and the master switched on the autopilot. The vesse's speed was increased to 10 knots. Gently turning to starboard, Freyja settled on a heading of 336. A few minutes later, the master called the second mate to check the soundings. As the latter reported the water depths, the master became concerned, switched to manual steering and strived to steer the vessel clear of the shallows. At 1255/20s, Freyja ran aground in position 61 35.83' N 004 58.13 E.

The safety investigation determined that the immediate cause of the accident was an unintended deviation from the planned course.

SummaryOfEvents: On 26 June 2017, at 19:20, the chemical oil tanker Nabucco was all fastened and berthed port side alongside British Petroleum (BP) Terminal number 1 jetty in Saltend, Hull, United Kingdom (UK). Two means of access were established. One gangway was installed to enable access in low water situation and the port side accommodation ladder was established for high water situations. At around 22:50 the means of access were required to be changed as the tide was on the ebb and the accommodation ladder needed to be stowed away. The gangway was prepared for accessing the vessel. The vessel's speed was too low, by comparison with the recommendations and best practices of the port. When the vessel was in the most critical step, the speed slowed down and the vessel experienced a loss of maneuvrability. She consequently yawed abruptly to portside and capsized. Eight persons, amongst the nine on board, were ejected to the water.A passenger and the AB seaman were drowned. Another passenger is still missing.The two engines were dismantled for the inquiry but the origin of the damage was not identified.

MSC Ravenna entered the Malta Freeport and berthed starboard side alongside at Terminal 2, North Quay on Wednesday 21 June 2017 at 1924. During her cargo discharge operation, the vessel was to bunker 700 metric tonnes of high sulphur fuel oil from a local bunker barge.

Two six inch diameter bunker hoses, connected together, were lifted using the vessel’s port side provisions crane and the bunker hose flange was connected to a reducer stub piece at the manifold. When the bunkering operation was terminated, the fitter and the wiper started to release the bolts of the reducer flange to which the bunker hose was tightened.As soon as the bunker hose flange was clear off the last bolt, the fitter was pulled backwards, still bracing the bunker hose as it swung towards the shipside.He eventually lost his balance and fell overboard to the bunker barge, sustaining fatal injuries.

Three portable pumps were transferred aboard but the water ingress could not be contained and the vessel sank releasing 18,900 litres of fuel oil into the sea. All 4 crew were rescued by the boat CG 45630. No injuries were reported. The hull damage was discovered the day prior to the incident.

Location: South China Sea 17 miles NE of Le Thuy, Quang Binh
SummaryOfEvents: The ship struck an unknown floating object and subsequently sank in the South China Sea 17 miles NE of Le Thuy, Quang Binh. The initial incident took place at 2010 hours LT (UTC+7) the previous evening. The ship sustained a breach in the hull and took on water in cargo hold no. 2. Vietnam border force patrol boats attended the scene and rescued all 10 crew with assistance from nearby fishing vessels. Survivors were taken to Dao Con Co the following morning. No injuries were reported. The ship subsequently sank. Oil pollution was reported on nearby beaches at Dao Con Co. A cleanup was effected. The floating object was assumed to be a drifting container.

ShipsInvolved: ACX CRYSTAL (IMO 9360611), MV ACX CRYSTAL (IMO 9360611), USS FITZGERALD (-)
SOLASStatus: ACX CRYSTAL: SOLAS, MV ACX CRYSTAL: SOLAS, USS FITZGERALD: Unknown/unspecified
Location: Izu Peninsula, 56 NM from the port of Yokosuka, Japan
SummaryOfEvents:
The US Navy ship USS FITZGERALD and the container ship ACX CRYSTAL collided at Izu Peninsula in Japan. 
Following the collision, USS FITZGERALD had severe damage on the starboard side and ACX CRYSTAL suffered minor damages in the bow section, without breaches.
Seven sailors from USS FITZGERALD went missing (then found dead) after the collision, no injuries reported by ACX CRYSTAL.

A French seaman was very seriously injured by the starboard fishing gear cable, suddenly released from the hull's side, while preparing to heave up the portside dredge (both cables were tangled). He was evacuated towards Brighton Hospital by an helicopter coming from Beachy Head (UK). 6 months after the accident, the seaman is still away from work.

Location: South Atlantic Ocean 36 miles NE of Puerto Rawson, Chubut
SummaryOfEvents: The ship took on water, listed and sank in the South Atlantic Ocean 36 miles NE of Puerto Rawson, Chubut in heavy weather. The ship Maria Liliana and Argentine Coast Guard ships, helicopters and aircraft effected SAR operation. Two crew were rescued, 3 were found dead and 7 were missing. Aerial surveillance found only liferafts, life jackets and an oil sheen at the scene. A two-month search failed to find the sunken vessel or any trace of the missing crew.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Total loss of the ship

Location: South Indian Ocean 260 miles NW of Iles Amsterdam, French Southern & Antarctic Lands
SummaryOfEvents:
The ship caught fire in the South Indian Ocean 260 miles NW of Iles Amsterdam, French Southern & Antarctic Lands in heavy weather.
All 25 crew abandoned ship to 2 liferafts. They were subsequently rescued by the ship Yuan You 516 with assistance from Yuan You 618 later the same day and taken to Port Louis, Mauritius. No injuries were reported. Salvage operations were not practical due to the severity of the fire and the risk of internal explosions. The ship was abandoned, completely burnt out and left drifting and presumed to have sunk.

Location: Rhodes Channel 2 miles NW of Akra Mylon, Rhodes
SummaryOfEvents: The ship caught fire in the engine room in the Rhodes Channel 2 miles NW of Akra Mylon, Rhodes. Three coastguard patrol vessels, 3 tugs and a HAF super puma helicopter attended the scene. Eighteen crew and 2 passengers abandoned the ship to a lifeboat and were taken to Rhodes. Twelve crew remained aboard to fight the blaze which was eventually extinguished. No injuries were reported. The ship sustained damage to the port main engine. LOF with scopic invoked. The ship was towed to safe anchorage off Rhodes for inspection. Laid up at Salamis Island and towed to Aliaga, Turkey in December 2017 for recycling.

On June 14, 2017 in the early afternoon, the ship MALUHEL is maneuvering in the port of Port-en-Bessin-Huppain. As a result of a failure on the reversing control system, the vessel is unable to stop the course.To cushion the shock with one of the ships moored nearby, the boss leaves the bridge and goes to the back beach. The MALUHEL approaches the bow of the ENEZ SUN ship and the skipper is violently hit on the head by the superstructure of the ships, causing his death.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Ship remains fit to proceed

SummaryOfEvents: KE-VERO's skipper was dragged overboard after becoming entangled by a string while shooting pots at fishing grounds, west of Batz Island. As he was alone onboard, his vessel continued to sail. Fortuntely, the NINJA 2, another vessel, was fishing in the vicinity and saw the vessel without anybody onboard. 15 minutes later, the KE-VERO's skipper was rescovered by NINJA 2; he was slightly injured and soon resumed his activity.

Location: Straits of Malacca, 11 nautical miles from Tanjung Kling
SummaryOfEvents:
The Indonesian cargo ship, KM AVATAR, capsized in the Straits of Malacca on Wednesday 14 June 2017, in the morning, with 15 crew members on board. Two crew members - the Captain and a cook - were reportedly still missing.

The Malaysian Maritime Enforcement Agency (MMEA) received a report from the marine department about the incident at 9.25am and deployed a rescue boat and helicopter to the scene.

13 members of ship’s crew were rescued by the merchant vessel, UNDINE, which was passing through the location of the incident - about 11 nautical miles from Tanjung Kling, Malacca.

The two crew members of the container ship  who went missing were found on Thursday 15, with one of them dead and the other alive

KM AVATAR, which is a 57-metre long ship, was initially half submerged but later sunk completely due to strong waves.

InitialEvent: Hull failure / failure of watertight doors / ports, etc.
SummaryOfEvents: On 12th July 2017, the floating dock PD-11 got sunk at the depth of 50 metres in the White Sea while being tugged by the ice breaker KAPITAN KOCOLAPOV from the Severodvinsk sea port to the Murmansk sea port due to the trouble of watertight integrity of the floating dock hull and undue measures taken in terms of shipboard damage control

SOLASStatus: AMBER L: SOLAS, CARMAL MATHA: Unknown/unspecified
Location: OFF THE COAST OF KOCHI, INDIA
SummaryOfEvents: Bulk carrier Amber L. (25955 gt, built 2000) came in contact with a fishing vessel Carmal Matha, killing two fishermen and injuring eleven others off the coast of Kochi, this morning. The vessel which reportedly left the scene after the incident has been detained along with its crew after an extensive search by the Indian Navy and Coast Guard. The injured fishermen have been admitted to various Kochi hospitals and the condition of two fishermen is stated to be serious. Another occupant of the fishing vessel is still missing and a search operation is ongoing.

A bulk carrier grounded when approaching port. The vessel was not damaged and refloated 12 hours later with tug assistance. It then anchored in safe water.On the next daylight high water, the vessel again touched the sea bottom when entering the port, but was able to continue to its berth. However, on this occasion, three of the ship's ballast tanks were breached, which required the vessel to dry dock for repair. Two harbour pilots were on board during the groundings.There was no pollution and no injuries.

Location: Bacia de Campos, Marlim Area Brazil
SummaryOfEvents: Boiler room explosion, 3 fatalities

The probe platform NORBE VIII (NS-32) was, carrying out the annual inspection of the boilers (certification) by the IMI company, by technicians, accompanied by the ship's engine officer when about 07:38 hours on June 9, 2017, there was an explosion in boiler number 01 reaching those three people who were inside the boiler compartment.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Serious injuries,Ship remains fit to proceed

SummaryOfEvents: On the 7th of June 2017, at approximately 04:13 , a Bulk Carrier under Bahamas flag grounded on the rocky coastline at the South Coast of Peloponnese (Kokkala - Greece), in position lat: 36 31,66 N, long: 022 28,37 E. At the time of the marine casualty, weather conditions were reported to be with very good visibility, wind force ENE 5-6 bfrs, sea was moderate and it was still dark.

On 6/7/2017 suddenly the main engine failed to work and on 8/7/2018 the related crew members tried to restart the engine several times but it failed to work and they then informed the owner company asking for a salvage unit for towing the ship and on 12 and 13 july the master sent a distress note

The ship broke anchor chains, struck the breakwater, took on water and partially sank in the Arabian Sea off Ullal, Karnataka in heavy monsoon weather. The ship was performing breakwater construction at the time of incident. The Indian Coast Guard despatched patrol vessel ICGS  Amartya, hovercraft H-196 and a helicopter to the scene. All 27 crew were rescued the following day. Some oil pollution was reported in the sea. Initial attempts to remove remaining bunkers were hampered by the adverse weather conditions. Containers and other debris from the barge washed ashore.

On June 02, 2017, around 07:00 hours, SW of the Jabuka island, occured an occupational accident where the chief engineer was injured while the ship was fishing. The injury occured when the chief engineer went to work to engine room and fell down. He injured his right leg and got an easier head injury.

On the afternoon of 20 June 2017, the fishing vessel Venessa S departed Port Stephens, New South Wales for Cabbage Tree Island. At approximately 1800, as Venessa S was approaching the island, the engine stopped and propulsion was lost. The skipper restarted the engine after several attempts however it was too late to avoid striking the bank. Venessa S struck the bank and started taking on water. The skipper and crew abandoned into a tender and Venessa S sank shortly after. The skipper and crew were rescued by the local water police about an hour later with no reported injuries.

While measuring the temperature, oxygen level, humidity level and sounding the bilges in the cargo holds, which were loaded with coal, an ASD entered the Australian ladder space for the No. 7 cargo hold. It was later determined he entered the space, which was classified as an enclosed space, without notifying the C/O or OOW, to recover a hydrometer.  The Bosun was also found in the Australian ladder space.  Presumably the Bosun had entered the space to assist the ASD.  Efforts to revive both seafarers were not successful.

Location: Selat Laut E of Pulau Swangi, Batu Licin, Kalimantan Selatan
SummaryOfEvents: The ship caught fire in Selat Laut E of Pulau Swangi, Batu Licin, Kalimantan Selatan in good weather. The crew’s attempts to extinguish the blaze were unsuccessful and requested assistance. Local authorities dispatched patrol vessels ' KNP 377' and ' KP XIII-39-1002' to the scene. All 11 crew were subsequently rescued, 2 sustained injuries and were given medical attention. The blaze was subsequently extinguished and an inspection effected. The ship was completely burned out. The cause of the fire was sparking from the pump during fuel transfer. The ship was towing barge ' NAUTICA 14' laden with coal at the time of incident.

The ship was stranded after dragging anchor on Parki beach, Anwara, Chittagong in heavy weather from cyclone Mora. No injuries or pollution were reported. The wreck was abandoned in situ. Recycling in situ had commenced by January 2019 but was subsequently suspended due to legal proceedings.

On 17 May 2017, the vessel MV Violet 1, an Oil/Chemical tanker, departed from Assaluyeh, a port in Iran on a passage to Tokuyama a port in Fukuoka, Japan. 
On 28 May 2017 at 1600 hours (LT), the vessel was in a position Lat 06° 21-6’ N, Long 93° 43.2 E in the Bay of Bengal heading towards the Malacca Strait, the crew were mustered for a Safety Meeting. The crew was waiting for Wiper, Oleksandr Chernyshenko to be present so the meeting could start. He did not turn up. After waiting for a few minutes, the 3rd Engineer called him on the telephone but there was no response. He then went to his cabin but he was not there and the cabin door was unlocked. The 3rd Engineer then checked other cabins and he was not to be found. It would appear that he was missing on board. 

At 1630 hours on the same day, the Master mustered all crew members and mounted a thorough search on board the ship for him. The search was carried out until 1930 hours (LT) on board with 45 minutes break for dinner and the usual D&A test conducted at 1800 hours. The crew checked and searched all the cabins including all store rooms, all bilges, corners and void spaces, in Engine Room, on deck and in the funnel, he was not to be found. There were no witnesses of his missing.  
The last time the Wiper was seen on board was by the Oiler 3 at 0330 hours on 28 May 2017.  He was seen on the alleyway of Deck B near his cabin when Oiler 3 was going on watch in the Engine Room.  
The statements of fact were taken from all crew members by the Master for the period from 1600 hours on 27 May 2017 till the time the Wiper was discovered missing. He was seen by various crew members on various occasions and places on board from 1600 hours on 27 May 2017 till 0330 hours on 28 May 2017. He was seen on upper deck, ER, during dinner time, alleyway of Deck A, TV room, and crew mail computer. 
From dinner time till 2330 hours on 27 May 2017, the Wiper was watching TV with 4th Engineer and the Oiler 3 (his friend). He also used the crew mail computer near the ship’s office on Deck A.
From 2300 hours on 27 May 2017 till 0330 hours on 28 May 2017, nobody had seen him. At 0330 hours on 28 May 2017, the Wiper was last seen by Oiler 3 in alleyway of Deck B going to his cabin.
At 1730 hours on 28 May 2017, the vessel was in open sea at the Lat 06° 21’N, Long 093° 42-8’ in the Bay of Bengal, Master commenced and mounted a Search and Rescue (SAR) operation, the vessel’s course was reversed 180º to proceed to the position where the Wiper was last seen on board. All relevant parties were informed. The Master transmitted urgent MOB messages through VHF radiotelephony, DSC, MF/HF calls. The DPA and MRCC Port Blair were notified. 
The SAR operations went on for 73 hours. As the man over board was not found, SAR operations were called off at 1830 hours on 31 May 2017. 
The vessel resumed its voyage to the port of destination, Tokuyama, Japan.

SOLASStatus: GAZ CENTURY: SOLAS, HATEM KOUSSAY: Unknown/unspecified
SummaryOfEvents:
27th May 2017 at about 06.45 LT ,our vessel Gaz Century while underway approximately at South West Sicily/Italy collided with a wooden fishing boat.
In accordance with the preliminary data obtained from the Master, 4 persons (of Tunisian nationality) from the fishing boat were rescued by Gaz Century, while  it is believed that 3 persons (of Tunisian nationality) from the fishing boat are missing.

At 1043 L T on May 25, 2017, a fire broke out in the engine room of the oil products tanker ZIRCON. At the time the vessel was on passage from Riga port to Skagen, abt. 15 NM off the Riga breakwaters, out of pilotage area having full sea speed. The ship was loaded with the cargo of 7268 tons of Gas Oil and Fiel Oil.
The navigational officer of the watch at 1043LT noticed the activation of the engine-room fire alarm and immediately phoned the engine control room to alert the engineering officer of the watch. The engineers took immediate action and confirmed that main engine was on fire.
Due to the intensity of the fire and the dense smoke, attempts to extinguish the fire with portable fire extinguishers could prove futile. Consequently, the engine-room had to be abandoned and prepared for CO2 release. 
The fire was eventually brought under control and extinguished after the activation of the fixed CO2 installation. No evacuation of the crew was needed. 
The Transport Accident and Incident Investigation Bureau (TAIIB) determines that the probable cause of fire on board the ZIRCON was the spray of fuel oil on a hot surface and igniting, following the fracture of the securing screw on the low pressure fuel supply pipes flange, located on the main engine.
Due to the breaking of a cleat when pulling the lines, two people sustained injuries.

On 22 May 2017, the second officer on the bulk carrier Nord Quebec was fatally injured during a mooring accident while the vessel was berthing at section 16 of the Port of Trois-Rivières, Quebec. There was no damage to the vessel, and no pollution was reported.

InitialEvent: Fatality on board caused by rolling logs
SummaryOfEvents: On 16 April 2017 , China flagged multi-purpose ship LE YE, a vessel owned by Cosco Shipping Specialized Carriers Co., Ltd departed Pointe-Noire, Congo with 17844.76 tons of Logs (3315 packages) on board. Proceeding to the destination port Zhangjiagang, China, the ship called at port Klang, Malaysia for the purpose of bunkering and at port Haipong, Vietnam for the purpose of discharging part of the cargo. When the ship was discharging part of the logs at the Halong Bay anchorage, Haipong port, Vietnam, the second officer on duty was crushed and killed by logs rolling down in the tween deck of cargo hold #1 at around 0115 on May 22.

SOLASStatus: BINH DUONG 658: Unknown/unspecified, HAI LINH 02: Unknown/unspecified
Location: Lach Huyen Channel near buoys 13-14 off Cat Hai, Haiphong
SummaryOfEvents:
The ship was in collision with the ship Hai Linh 02, took on water and sank in the Lach Huyen Channel near buoys 13-14 off Cat Hai, Haiphong in poor visibility.
No injuries or pollution were reported. The ship sustained serious damage to the starboard side of the hull adjacent to the No. 2 hold. Attempted to proceed to Cat Hai with assistance from patrol boats despatched by local authorities but sank enroute at 2036 LT due to ingress of water. The crew sealed all valves and tank vents prior to sinking. Three crew were rescued by the ship Hai Linh 02 and the remaining 5 rescued by Vietnam Border Defence vessels. The wreck was marked with a warning buoy.

Location: Java Sea 5 miles S of Pulau Masalembo Besar
SummaryOfEvents:
The ship caught fire from a truck on 'D' vehicle deck and drifted in the Java Sea 5 miles S of Pulau Masalembo Besar.
Initial attempts to extinguish the fire were unsuccessful, so an evacuation was ordered. Nearby ships including Dharma Kartika IX assisted in the rescue operation. 187 passengers and crew rescued were taken to Tanjung Perak, 3 passengers were taken to Masalembo. Another 2 passengers were rescued by Meratus Makassar and taken to Makassar, 1 of whom later died. Five bodies were recovered by local fishermen. The drifting burnt out ship was subsequently stranded 2 miles E of Masalembo.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Total loss of the ship

Location: South China Sea 28 miles SE of Jinwan, Zhuhai
SummaryOfEvents: The ship took on water in the steering gear compartment and sank in the South China Sea 28 miles SE of Jinwan, Zhuhai. The crew attempted to control the ingress of water with portable pumps but this was unsuccessful and the flooding spread to the engine room. All 8 crew abandoned ship to 2 liferafts and were subsequently rescued by the ship Pampero. No injuries were reported. The wreck was removed by 20/07/17 with assistance from the crane barge Nan Tian Long and tug De Cheng.
The vessel grounded when approaching the Port of Mombasa. The vessel tried to use main engines to re-float but was unsuccessful hence the tugs were called in to assist.

Location: Sea of Okhotsk 19 miles W of Ozernovskiy, Ust-Bolsheretsky, Kamchatka
SummaryOfEvents: The ship caught fire in the crew accommodation and was disabled whilst fishing in the sea of Okhotsk 19 miles W of Ozernovskiy, Ust-Bolsheretsky, Kamchatka. The blaze spread to the superstructure. The crew of 22 were evacuated to the ship Real. The remaining 5 crew unsuccessfully attempted to extinguish the blaze and were later evacuated to Limanskiy. No injuries were reported. The rescue tug Suvorovets arrived at the scene on 19/05/17. The blaze was extinguished and towed to anchorage 7 miles off Ozernovskiy where the cargo was transferred to the ship Marine Star. The ship arrived at Busan towed by the tug Grif on 04/06/17. Damaged beyond economical repair.

At about 0030 (UTC +8) on 17 May 2017, Gortynia, a fully laden cape size bulk carrier, collided with bulk carrier DZ Qingdao in Singapore Strait. The collision occurred in the East-bound deep water route of the traffic separation scheme (TSS) off Batu Berhanti.

Gortynia sustained major damage to her port side forward ballast tanks both above and below the waterline. The vessel also sustained varying degrees of damage to the port side hull and deck fittings from cargo hold no. 1 to just forward of the accommodation. DZ Qingdao also sustained major damages to her bow. Both vessels were able to proceed to an anchorage, off Singapore where the respective damages were assessed.

The safety investigation concluded that prior to DZ Qingdao suffering a power loss resulting in a temporary loss of propulsion and steering, both vessels were approaching each other in their respective traffic separation lanes and were to pass clear of each other.  The change in DZ Qingdao s heading and speed meant that she now was at risk of collision with Gortynia as they approached each other.  This change was not noted on board Gortynia as the bridge team were only monitoring AIS targets on its radars, and with the loss of power on board DZ Qingdao, the AIS transmission ceased, causing the loss of the AIS plot.

DZ Qingdao did not warn VTIS and the surrounding vessels that she was not under command and as a result when the change in heading was detected by Gortynia, at a very late stage, this did not allow her  to take effective avoiding action in time to avoid the collision.

The ship struck the breakwater whilst approaching Hakata, Fukuoka in good weather. All 3 crew sustained injuries and were taken to hospital where one subsequently died. No pollution was reported. The ship sustained serious damage to bulbous bow and forward mast. Berthed for inspection. Repairs were effected. A section of the breakwater sustained damage.

Location: Arabian sea 65 miles SW of Ratnagiri
SummaryOfEvents: The ship sank in the Arabian sea 65 miles SW of Ratnagiri. The rig was under tow to a recycling facility at the time of the incident.

TURKISH FLAG GENERAL CARGO/CONTAINER VESSEL ALI AGA LISTED DANGEROUSLY TO HER PORT SIDE DURING LOADING IN BANDIRMA CELEBI 9TH PIER. SOON AFTER THE VESSEL CAPSIZED. ALL CREW AND PORT WORKERS WERE SAFELY RESCUED. SOME OF THEM HAD SUFFERED SLIGHT INJURY. SLIGHT OIL POLLUTION WAS REPORTED. THE VESSEL WAS REFLOATED AFTER A SUCCESSFUL SALVAGE OPERATION IN JULY 2017. ALL CONTAINERS HAD TAKEN OUT FROM WATER AND THE PIER WAS CLEARED RESPECTIVELY.

On 13 May 2017, the Maltese registered bulk carrier Universal Durban, while on passage from Bell Bay, Tasmania to Bintulu, Malaysia, ran aground on a shoal at 12 knots, South of the island of Pulau Serasan in position 02 14.65 N 109 05.17 E.

The vessel sustained minor damages in the bow area and bottom shell plating, in way of no. 1 cargo hold.  No damage was found in the internal structures and the vessel s watertight integrity was not breached.  There was no pollution and no injuries were reported.

The safety investigation revealed that the scale of digital chart in use on ECDIS was unsuitable for the area and the quality of data encoded within the composite data quality attribute of that chart was not within the thresholds defined by the category of zone of confidence.

Location: Arzoo International Terminal, Hamriyah Sharjah – United Arab Emirates
SummaryOfEvents:
The MT ROJEAN is a Panama Flag Oil Tanker built in 1991 by Singapore Shipbuilding & Engineering Ltd. and has a service speed of 11.40 knots. At the time of the incident the vessel was classed by International Maritime Register (IMR) . 
The vessel had a total ten (10 Port & Stbd) cargo oil tanks and two (2) slop tanks which were located forward of the accommodations. Propulsion power is provided by an Akasaka Diesel Limited, single acting, and diesel engine. The engine drives a single, fixed pitch propeller. The technical managers and ISM operators for the vessel is Al Rafadein Marine Service LLC. (IMO No. 5480887). 
The vessel suffered an explosion while loading cargo berthed at Hamriyah Sharjah U.A.E., inner harbor jetty, on May 13th, 2017.  On May 12th, 2017 while the vessel was loading cargo oil, the duty officers and the crew stopped loading operation due to visible degradation and color change of the loaded cargo, due to mixing with the vessel’s deck piping and manifold had remaining of previous cargo, despite vessel just coming from an intermediate drydock on April 7th, 2017. Due to this, owner decided to use this contaminated oil as vessel’s bunker consumption and instructed the crew to transfer the contaminated product to one of the vessel F.O. storage tank using two (2) submersible electric pumps.  
It is believed that these electric pumps were the source of ignition for the explosion.

On May 13,2017 @ 05:27, a fire explosion happened on board the Panamanian flagged vessel M/T. Rojean , while she was alongside berth # 2 inner harbour of Hamriyah Port - Sharjah, United Arab Emirates.
A shore firefighting team fought and extinguished the fire effectively within about TWO hours.
This accident resulted in the death of an able seaman and a motorman severely injured moreover an assistant terminal operator was checking the loading hose ashore and his back was burn.
Severely injured motorman was treated in the hospital for 12 days, and due to his severe injury he died on May 25, 2017.

After finishing his activity (wrack fishing) F/V SAINT BERNARD fully loaded went back to LANDEDA harbour for unloading. Weather conditions were rough with a wind and sea state increasing . In the vicinity of Rosservo Island the skipper had a radio distress call, his ship was suddently sinking. Mayday relay was launched with MRCC and assistance with fishing vessel and rescue boat SNSM were quickly on scene. The body lifeless of the skipper was recovered and the F/V sunk near Rosservo Island.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Ship rendered unfit to proceed,Total loss of the ship

Location: Mediterranean Sea 10 miles SW of Malta
SummaryOfEvents: The ship sustained mechanical problems and drifted in the Mediterranean Sea 10 miles SW of Malta. The ship was taken in tow of unknown tug to Marsaxlokk, Malta arriving on 09/05/17 for cargo discharge and inspection. Subsequently arrived at a shipyard in Valletta on 12/05/17 for drydocking and further inspections. Damaged beyond economical repair and towed to Aliaga for recycling.

Location: Guishan anchorage South West of Hong Kong
SummaryOfEvents: Shore worker died as a result of injuries due to fall from height while cleaning No.1P cargo oil tank.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Ship remains fit to proceed

InitialEvent: Hull failure / failure of watertight doors / ports, etc.
SummaryOfEvents: The ship sustained a crack in the hull, took on water and sank whilst anchored off Talisay. The hull cracked vertically amidships and sagged severely prior to sinking. All 22 crew were rescued and taken ashore by the tug Tug 38. No injuries were reported. Some oil leaked into the water and the oil boom was deployed to contain the spill. The ship was moored alongside Paros Seas and had just been loaded with a cargo of steel billets discharged from this ship.

Location: Java Sea 5 miles NW of Pulau Bawean
SummaryOfEvents: The ship developed a list to port, took on water in the engine room, capsized and sank in the Java Sea 5 miles NW of Pulau Bawean in heavy weather. The list started to develop several hours earlier, the crew attempted to correct it by transferring ballast water but were unsuccessful. When the list increased to 12 degrees all 8 crew abandoned ship to a liferaft. They were subsequently rescued by local fishing boats, transferred to a passing ship, Tanto Bersama and taken to Tanjung Priok, Jakarta. No injuries were reported.

Location: Suva Harbour off the south end of King's Wharf
SummaryOfEvents:
The ship developed a list to port, took on water and subsequently capsized in Suva Harbour off the south end of King's Wharf, Suva.
The list occurred whilst loading cargo at Princess Wharf at 0100 hours lt. The ship was subsequently towed away from the wharf. All crew were evacuated. No injuries were reported. Oil pollution was reported and containment measures were effected. At least 30 containers fell overboard which were later recovered. LOF contracted to Ardent Maritime UK as salvors. The remaining bunker oil was removed. Pacific Towing Ltd refloated the wreck in March 2019. The ship was subsequently scuttled 7 miles offshore on 25/05/19.

At about 1345hrs local time on 5th May 2017, China flagged multi-purpose ship Da Zhi, owned by COSCO Shipping Specialized Carriers Co., Ltd, made heavy contact with the quay and shore crane while executing a berthing at Abidjan Port, Coate d'Ivoire. The starboard bow of the vessel struck the shore container crane and caused the latter collapse to one side, part of the containers damaged and the manger board on starboard bow damaged.

Location: port of Donje Celo - Island Kolocep
SummaryOfEvents: On May 05. marine incident occured when passenger ship "Premuda" entering into harbour Donje Celo - island Kolocep. Due to a malfunction of the right propulsion machinery control system there was a strike on the shore. There was no injuries or no polluttion of the sea.

Location: Southern Ocean 75 miles NE of the South Shetland Islands
SummaryOfEvents: The ship sustained ingress of water to no. 2 cargo hold after striking ice in the Southern Ocean 75 miles NE of the South Shetland Islands. No injuries or pollution were reported. The ship was diverted towards the Falkland Islands but crew efforts to contain the flooding were unsuccessful. Argentine Navy P-3B aircraft flew over the scene. Flooding spread to Nos. 1 and 3 cargo holds and the ship lost power. All 42 crew were rescued at 0500 hours LT on 07/05/17 by the ship Taganrogskiy Zaliv. The ship was taken in tow by Frio Las Palmas under escort of the tug Otway and eventually sank 400 miles NE of the Falkland Islands on 16/05/17.

On May 5, 2017, the fishing vessel IZEL-VOR is proceeding to Lorient after having loaded all of its nets 16 miles into the south of Groix island . After passing the cap of the Cats of the island of Groix, the fishing vessel accuses a lodging on port side. The skipper to try to restore the heeling asks the crew to empty the port fishpond and move some fishing gears on the starboard side. At 2 miles from the buoy Bastresses South, the vessel accentuates her heeling on the port side and loads water through the port bow. The vessel capsized less than one minute later, around noon in Courreaux de Groix. The three seamen manage to climb on the hull returned. The EPIRB is triggered and alert is sent. The skipper, trying to leave the bridge that is invaded, finds himself to the crew accomodation where there is a pocket of air. The vessel floats upside down between two waters. Upon rescue arrival, the three sailors are recovered and transported to the hospital. Divers cannot access the accomodation in which the skipper is blocked. The decision is made to tow the wreck to Cour gant Beach to ground. The divers take turns on the hull to maintain a permanent contact with the skipper. Around 17:30, once the hull grounded, it is cut. The skipper is removed from the vessel and picked up by the rescue five hours after the capsize. On Sunday, May 7th, the wreck is towed out of the water and stored on the dock in Lorient.
Consequences1: Pollution,Serious injuries,Ship rendered unfit to proceed,Total loss of the ship

SummaryOfEvents: While berthing, the container ship contacted the quay, resulting in damage to the ship, quay and two shore cranes.

The ship took on water and partially sank whilst berthed at the Kumcular Wharf at Kartal, Istanbul. No injuries or pollution were reported. Forward part of vessel submerged and resting on bottom of berth. The vessel had sustained hull damage in a previous stranding incident in December 2016 and had been laid up under arrest for some time. The ship was refloated and arrived in tow at Aliaga on 04/05/18 for recycling.

At approx. 1545 on 3rd May 2017, HSC Condor Liberation was manoeuvring within St Peter Port harbour in order to moor at No 1 berth. The vessel made contact with the small craft pontoon in the outer pool area of the port, as well as a private sailing catamaran and the starboard hand lateral mark.  This caused damage to the pontoon and a catamaran berthed on the pontoon’s south side. Condor Liberation subsequently berthed without further incident.

On May 02, 2017, Position Lat 07-06.5 N Long 079-30.2 W, during vessel passage from Balboa, Spain to Guayaquil, Ecuador with a calm sea, clear sky and good visibility, about 1430 LT, the Deck Cadet, who was working at the ship’s office heard loud thud on deck and went out from accommodation, found that 3rd.Officer lying face down at Aft of accommodation deck. Deck cadet immediately informed to bridge Officer on Watch (OOW) and run to Engine Control Room for help. OOW informed the incident to Master and Chief Officer. At 1438 LT, went down on deck to check and confirmed that 3rd. Officer was badly injured and not moving regardless of calling out his name. At 1439 LT, Master went down and assessed the scene, confirmed that 3rd. Officer had no vital signs. Master declared the 3rd. officer’s death at 1440 LT and reported to DPA. As instructed by DPA, deceased body had transferred to reefer container.
