On Sunday April 30, an able seaman (AB) washed down the ships side from the pier in Levanger, Norway. The AB moved sideways along the ships side when washing. When he moved onto an area where the pier narrowed, he took a step backwards and stumbled on the guardrail on the pier. He fell down backwards and hit his head on some rocks below the pier. The AB died the following day from the injuries sustained. In addition to a review of the companys and the ships procedures for risk assessment and routines for working at the pier, the AIBN has looked at safety issues related to inspections, construction of the pier and relevant regulations. In order to increase the safety for crew working at the pier, a railing has been fitted on the pier after the accident. The AIBN has not identified other areas of relevance to prevent future marine accidents. The AIBN has thus not issued any safety recommendations related to this accident..

AN EXPLOSION OCCURRED ON SEA SURFACE AND SERVICE BOAT NAMED "SERDAR 2" RESPECTIVELY, DURING SHIFTING MACHINERY SPARES AND SHORE WORKERS TO TURKISH FLAG LPG CARRIER VESSEL "HABAS". AS A RESULT OF EXPLOSION, A FIRE STARTED ON SERDAR 2. THE FIRE WAS EXTINGUISHED BY HABAS CREW AND TUG BOATS. AFTER EXPLOSION ANOTHER SERVICE BOAT NAMED "EFE HUSEYIN" RESCUED MANY OF CASUALTIES FROM SERDAR 2 AND TRANSFERRED THEM TO SHORE AND HOSPITAL RESPECTIVELY. AS A CONSEQUENCE, 9 PEOPLE WERE INJURED AND OTHER ONE WAS DEAD. SERDAR 2 WAS ENTIRELY BURNED. A SLIGHT STAIN DAMAGE OCCURRED ON HABAS STBD SIDE OF 4TH CARGO TANK. NO POLLUTION WAS REPORTED.

Location: Pier B, Dock Sud, Buenos Aires
SummaryOfEvents:
The ship was in collision with tug Ona Don Lorenzo whilst berthing with tug assistance at pier B, Dock Sud, Buenos Aires.
No injuries were reported. Sustained damage to the hull. An unknown quantity of oil leaked into the water. Local authorities deployed anti-pollution booms and effected clean-up operation. Subsequently arrived at Tadanor shipyard, Buenos Aires for inspection and repairs.

SOLASStatus: Aries: Unknown/unspecified, ARIES: Unknown/unspecified, COSTA LUMINOSA: Unknown/unspecified
SummaryOfEvents: On 28.04.2017. at 12:00 o'clock, during berthing of the passenger ship Costa Luminosa at the port of Gaženica, during the assistance, there where contact with tugboat "Aries". There was no injured people or no pollution of sea.

YOUZARSIF II collided with a Russian navy ship 'LIMAN' whilst underway in the Black Sea 16 miles north of Agacli, Istanbul, Turkey. 
YOUZARSIF II had minor damage and proceeded to Midia, Romania for discharge of undelivered cargo and inspection. Russian navy ship 'LIMAN' sustained hole to starboard hull below waterline and subsequently sank. All 78 of crew of LIMAN were safely rescued.

The ship caught fire and subsequently capsized whilst undergoing repairs alongside berth at Agadir. 
Tug Tilila attended the scene to provide assistance. The blaze was extinguished by firefighters. Reported blaze originated from welding operations on board and ship developed list to starboard prior to capsizing due to ingress of water during fire extinguishing operations. Two firefighters and one worker sustained injuries and were sent to local hospital for medical attention.

The Portuguese flagged vessel, MV Talassa, departed from Singapore. After departed the officer of the watch (OOW) reported to the chief officer (CO) that the spring rope from the aft station got stacked on the tension drum and that one strand of the rope was damaged. On 26.04.2017, the CO, together with the ship’s bosun, decided to inspect the rope, cut the damaged part and make a new eye on the mooring rope or, to replace the rope with a new one, if necessary. At 08:30 hours they laid the rope on the ship’s main deck. CO was operating the mooring winch and bosun tried to release the stacked rope between the loops on the tension drum by hammering it, without success. CO and bosun decided to fast the rope on a bollard and use the winch. After 3 attempts the rope was not released and bosun went to check the location of the stack rope on the drum. The rope was suddenly released and hit the bosun in the head. At 10:00 hours bosun was declared dead

On 26. April 2017. at 09.50h high speed craft Karolina was in Preko harbour on the regular line Zadar - Preko. Due to the turbulent sea and the strong southern wind there was damage to the hull of the ship on the left side of the bow about 1,5m above the waterline, with 0,15 meters. There was a crushing of the hull of the ship. There was no injuries or no pollution of the sea.

Location: Moored at the Vuurtorendok at Ostend
SummaryOfEvents:
The ship sank whilst moored at the Vuurtorendok at Ostend.
No injuries were reported. Some oil pollution was reported in the water. Local emergency services deployed anti pollution booms. Aft part of tug submerged with bow still above the water. The tug had been laid up unmanned for some years and was in a poor state of repair. Wreck refloated with assistance from floating crane Hebo Lift 7 on 26/09/17, lifted on to a barge and taken to Scheepssloperij van der Gucht, Antwerp for recycling.

On 25.04.2017. The passenger ship Melita on the regular passenger line Zadar - Bršanj at the Bršanj harbour, due to the strong SE wind had contact with the coast. The ship leaned by side on the ferry ramp where the left bow has been damaged. There was no pollution of the sea.

During morning inspection, a fire broke out in the Bosun Stores when a light was turned on.  One crew member died due to burns and three crew members were serious injured.

The ship broke port anchor chain, drifted and stranded on rocky shoreline at Sidon in strong winds.
Sustained damage to hull and took on water. No injuries or pollution were reported. Diving inspection was effected. Initial refloating attempts were unsuccessful. Further refloating attempts by tugs on 08/05/17 were only partially successful, the ship moved 15 metres before the tow parted. Salvors removed bunker fuel and some cargo lightered. Refloated on 12/06/17 and towed to berth at Sidon for inspection. Subsequently arrived at Aliaga on 21/06/17 for recycling.

Location: Muelle de la Esfinge, Las Palmas de Gran Canaria
SummaryOfEvents:
The ship sustained diesel generator failure, lost power and struck the Muelle de la Esfinge, whilst departing Las Palmas de Gran Canaria.
Sustained damage to forepeak and bulbous bow. 13 passengers were injured with 5 of them sent to hospital for medical attention. Temporary repairs were effected 1 hour later and proceeded to the Astican shipyard under escort of 2 tugs for inspection and repairs. A section of the pier sustained serious damage and at least 25,000 litres of fuel from a damaged pipe inside the pier leaked into the sea. Local authorities effected oil spill containment and cleanup efforts.

Location: Quay at the Muelle de Isla Verde, Algeciras
SummaryOfEvents:
Sank after breaking moorings and striking quay at the Muelle de Isla Verde, Algeciras in strong winds.
No injuries or pollution were reported. The ship was lying on port side on bottom of berth partially submerged. The ship had been laid up since 2013 having been abandoned by the owners and was unmanned at the time of the incident. Anti-pollution boom was deployed as a precaution although bunker fuel had previously been removed. Salvors Ardentia Marine refloated the ship in October 2017. Departed Algeciras in tow of tug World Tug 1 on 23/06/18 bound for unknown port for recycling.

On 19 April 2017, a fire broke out in the engine-room of the Maltese registered chemical tanker Usichem. At the time, the vessel was sailing in a laden condition, about 40 nautical miles off Rhodes Island, on a voyage from Taman, Russia to the port of Sudan, Sudan.

The first crew member to notice the fire on the main engine was the vessel s electrician and promptly alerted other crew members, although no alarm was activated. The main engine was stopped by the chief engineer, who tried to extinguish the fire with a portable CO2 fire extinguisher. Eventually, the fire alarm automatically activated at 1030 (LT).

Eventually, the flames and heavy smoke overwhelmed the crew members and the fire was deemed uncontrollable. Consequently, the engine-room was evacuated at 1035 and all crew members mustered on the poop deck. At around 1110, the fire was extinguished using the vessel s fixed CO2 system. The vessel was towed to Istanbul, Tuzla to affect permanent repairs.

The immediate cause of the fire was identified to be a spray of fuel oil and diesel oil (IFO / MDO) mixture on the hot turbo charger housing.

Location: In the Black Sea 36 miles W of Anapa
SummaryOfEvents:
Broke in two and sank in the Black Sea 36 miles W of Anapa in heavy weather.
Ships Armada Navigator, Barnet, Aelos and Episkopi, rescue tug Spasatel Demidov and 2 MI-8 helicopters effected SAR operations. 1 crew member was rescued by Tanker-18 suffering from severe hypothermia. Bodies of 2 crew were recovered by Spasatel Demidov and a further body was recovered by an MI-8 helicopter. 8 crew remain missing. Divers inspection of the submerged wreck failed to locate any of the missing crew.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Total loss of the ship

SummaryOfEvents:
On 17 April 2017 at about 1530H, two shipyard workers involved in an unmooring operation in Keppel Shipyard (Benoi), were injured as a result of being struck by the opened bight from a mooring line tail rope used for the mooring of a liquefied natural gas (LNG) tanker. One of them was fatally injured.

The investigation revealed that the tail rope of the mooring line had been seized using a seizing twine to make a smaller eye (bight) for the purpose of securing onto smaller bollards ashore. As the ship’s crew slackened two of the three mooring lines (on the same bollard), the seizing twine of the mooring line that had likely taken load, parted, while the tail of the mooring line was intact. As a result, the opened up bight of the tail of the mooring line struck two workers who were preparing to release the slackened mooring lines from the bollard.
collision with a fishing boat while sailing

Took water and sank whilst moored at passenger berth no. 1 at Ulyanovsk. 
No injuries or pollution were reported. The ship had been laid up unmanned since 2010 and was in a poor state of repair. Cause of water ingress was the failure of seawater inlet valves. The ship was lying on the bottom of the berth listing to starboard and partially submerged. Local port authorities conducted a diver’s inspection prior to refloating and removal of the wreck.

Struck quay whilst berthing at berth no. 2, Pampushamnen, Norrkoping in strong winds.
Subsequently re-moored at the berth for inspection. Sustained a small hole in the hull and ruptured a bunker fuel tank. 1,000 litres of fuel leaked into the water. The Swedish coast guard despatched patrol vessels KBV 305, KBV 310, KBV 473 and KBV 050 to attend the scene and effected oil spill cleanup. Inspection and repairs were effected.

On April 14, 2017, at about 1128 LT, while vessel sailed from Adelaide, Australia to Port of Jakarta, Indonesia Duty Officer heard loud thud sound and started to look for Cadet. They found Cadet fell about 21 meters from the Bridge deck to the top of the container at bay 50 03 82. Cadet was lying unconscious with weak breathing and pulse, Master sent out distress calls, and established communication with MRCC Australia to communicate the incident. The vessel deviated her course to a rendezvous point given by MRCC Australia, after several information exchanged, the Cadet was pronounced dead by a doctor over radio medical advice, and helicopter rendezvous was cancelled.
Wiper was found dead on board; suspected of a fall from height.

At 1705 on 08 April 2017, while carrying out repairs in cargo hold no. 3, the third engineer fell approximately six meters from the cargo hold s ladder, just under the cargo hold s access ladder lower platform, to the tank top.

One of the crew members who was in the cargo hold raised the alarm. The injured crew member was attended by the chief and fourth engineers, who were on the main deck near the cargo hold no. 3.  Paramedics boarded the vessel some time later but the injured crew member was pronounced dead.

The safety investigation found that the immediate cause of the accident was the crew member losing his footing and grip whilst carrying out repairs on the ladder.
Explosion in gasoline engine compartment on board a recreationnal craf (motorboat Bavaria 32 sport), 2 passengers severly burnt, after people rescued, the motorboat was towed to Bandol port.

SummaryOfEvents:
The Myanmar's passenger ferry SILVER STAR was going from Pathein to Yakhinekone village in the Ngawun river, carrying about 66 people. Most of the ferry's passengers were returning from a wedding ceremony.

After colliding with a river barge carrying gravel, the passenger ferry capsized in the river at around 7:30 p.m, killing 20 people and leaving more than a dozen missing.

Both ships were unlit when they collided in the middle of the river.

Thirty people were rescued.

The shore authority was alerted by a person on the sea bank who saw the vessel stranded with the engine still running and nobody on board. The body of the skipper was found off Guernesey Island 7 weeks later.

Around 2318LT (UTC 1518) M/V XIANG ZHOU sank immediately after collision with a container vessel at the sea area 5 miles from No.2 Changjiangkou anchorage (the container vessel is suspected to be involved in the collision with M/V:XIANG ZHOU, this vessel has been instructed to return back to WUSONG anchorage for investigation).

On 05 April 2017, the electrician on board the Maltese registered bulk carrier Abyo Audrey suffered fatal injuries while working inside the elevator shaft.
The electrician had been working with the electro-technical trainee when work was stopped for the day. However, at about 1745 (LT), when the electrician had not shown up for dinner, the trainee engineer became concerned and informed the chief engineer. A search of the area where the electrician was last known to be working was carried out and he was eventually found inside the elevator shaft, trapped between the counterweight and a protective beam.
The alarm was raised and the crew rushed to release him and administered first aid, including resuscitation, but he did not respond. He was pronounced dead at the scene. The master immediately informed the company Designated Person Ashore (DPA) and the local authorities.
The safety investigation concluded that although safety procedures had been observed throughout the day of the accident, the entry into the elevator shaft without being assisted and in communication with other crew member, was a contributing factor to this accident.

On 5 April 2017 while Majesty of the Seas was in the port of Nassau, a routine crew emergency drill was was conducted. As part of the drill all watertight doors were remotely closed from the bridge. At the same time, another crewmember not involved in the drill was replacing black water pipes in the passenger accommodation area. He was observed leaving his work site on CCTV and proceeded to the engine room workshop holding various parts in his hand. When passing through WTD 18 to enter the engine room. on his way back while passing through the door a second time the crewmember was trapped and crushed between the door sustaining critical injuries. He was taken off the ship by ambulance to a shoreside medical facility and later transferred to a South Florida for further medical care.
Consequences1: Serious injuries,Ship remains fit to proceed

Location: Indian Sea East - Sri Lanka South
SummaryOfEvents:
The MSC DANIELA was engaged on a voyage from Singapore to Suez, covering a total of approximately 4,950 nautical miles.
The voyage was started from various ports in the Far East to the Mediterranean covering a full voyage within approximately 2 months.
The vessel had loaded a total of seven thousand six hundred and forty three (7,643) containers. Among that cargo a total of 4,219 tonnes corresponded to various hazardous cargoes of IMO class 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 8 and 9

On the 04th April 2017 the vessel was sailing on the south of Sri Lanka towards Suez at a speed of almost 20 knots under a gentle breeze and a slight sea and a crew of twenty five (25) persons.

At 08,15 hrs. while in position 06º31.0´W, 077 56.2´E a rumble noise like drums falling on deck somewhere outside the ship´s superstructure were heard and felt with a slight vibration.
Immediately black smoke was seen from the navigational bridge looking aft followed by large flames on the starboard side between bays 54 and 58.

Immediately thereafter an emergency announcement was made and all crew mustered.

The fire was spreading quickly among other containers and while the main engine had been stopped, all crew were engaged in the fire fighting using fire hoses.	

A tug arrived to the scene approximately two hours after and started spraying water on the fire in the starboard side. Another tug boat arrived soon after but was unable to spray water due to a technical problem on the fire fighting system.

	The MSC DANIELA was diverted to the nearest port of Colombo in Sri Lanka road where other tugboats would join to spray water onto the smoky and burning containers.

The fire resulted in minor damages to the hull, deck and pontoons as well as localised fittings on the upper deck.

	No crew suffered injuries and no casualties were reported.

	No pollution reported.

SOLASStatus: DAN FIGHTER: Unknown/unspecified, MAERSK GENOA: Unknown/unspecified
SummaryOfEvents:
The very large container ship MAERSK GENOA was breached in collision with freighter DAN FIGHTER at Borssele in Netherlands on the main waterway between Breskens and Vlissingen. The container carrier left Antwerp bound to Bremerhaven, when were hit by the cargo ship, which was proceeding to Belgium port.

 Following the collision, MAERSK GENOA suffered breaches in the stern, but above the waterline and without danger from water ingress. The container carrier didn’t lost any containers and reported no injuries. The freighter suffered damages in the bow section, but without breaches.

Both ships were advised to drop anchor and detained for further investigation. The root cause of the accident and the responsibilities will be assessed.

Location: In Indian ocean west of Sri Lanka
SummaryOfEvents:
MSC DANIELA, en route from Singapore to Suez, caught fire in Indian ocean west of Sri Lanka on 04 April 2017.
The crew tried to extinguish the fire, but was unable to get control over it during the first minutes. The crew changed course to Colombo, Sri Lanka and sent distress signal to the local authorities, requesting immediate assistance. At the scene of the burning container ship, two tugs were deployed for fighting the fire. Also Sri Lanka Navy dispatched two Fast Attack Craft (FAC),  which might evacuate the vessel in case of emergency

The vessel successfully reached Colombo anchorage, where was secured during firefighting. There is no information about injuries and pollution.

At 1030 on 03 April 2017, as a result of hot work on the starboard side of the m/v VF TANKER 7, moored in the port of the shipyard “Flotsky Arsenal”- Varna, a fire broke out in the space between the ship and the quay. One minute later, an explosion in the starboard ballast tank No 7 occurred. The cause for the fire was the presence of a film of the oil products on the water surface between the vessel and the quay. The cause for the explosion was the presence of an oil fumes in the ballast tank. The fire was extinguished by the crew and the ashore fire brigade.
No crew members and shipyard workers injured. No pollution due to the incident. The ship has suffered significant damage to the structure.
The BMAIU investigation found out that the root cause of the serious accident was the failure of the ship's officers to comply with the requirements of the basic documents concerning the safety of shipping operations, as well as failure by the shipyards' representatives to comply with the fire safety rules and the lack of control over the prevention of pollution of the port's aquatory.
The shipping company VF TANKER has taken actions to organize additional instructions, aiming to improve onboard trainings, to enhance Masters’ monitoring for the fulfilment of SMS requirements and increase the number of fleet audits. 
The shipyard “Flotsky Arsenal”- Varna has taken actions to review and update safety instructions and increase the number of “gas-free” inspectors. 
The shipyard “Flotsky Arsenal”- Varna has been recommended to review and, as appropriate, amend its safety management system to ensure safety ship repairing operations and pollution preventing.

On April 01, 2017 at about 1306 LT, position Lat 16-12.1 N Long 056-12.8 E while vessel enroute from Khorfakkan, UAE to Port Sudan, Sudan, Chief Engineer informed to Master that fire in Engine room and fire activated. At 1307 LT while mustering noted that Electrician was missing and vessel became black out. Commenced boundary cooling, emergency squad entering the engine room to fight the fire and to search the missing Electrician. At 1505 LT found death Electrician’s burned body lying adjacent to two barrels of silica gel close to thermal oil boiler. The deceased body had taken out through skylight to deck. At 1515 LT, sky light. At 1516 Lt, head counted again and confirmed all crews accounted then closed engine room vent flaps, skylights and engine room main door. At 1518 LT, released CO2 and continued boundary cooling.

Location: South China Sea 10 miles NE of Cam Ranh
SummaryOfEvents:
The ship took on water in the engine room, lost power and subsequently sank in the South China Sea 10 miles NE of Cam Ranh in heavy weather.
The crew noticed an ingress of water at 2330 hours lt the previous evening and requested assistance. Attempts to pump out water were unsuccessful and all 8 crew and 1 passenger abandoned ship to a liferaft at 0645 hours lt. All were rescued by nearby ship Bao Hoang 18 later the same morning. No injuries were reported. Survivors were subsequently transferred to local ship CVNT 2 and taken to Ba Ngoi port, Cam Ranh. Abandoned waterlogged ship left drifting and subsequently sank.

Sank whilst moored at the Novaya Kanonerskaya port, St Petersburg, circa April 2017. 
Partially submerged listing wreck lying on bottom of berth. No injuries were reported. The ship had been laid up unmanned since 2008.

SummaryOfEvents: Ship reported missing and presumed sunk.  It was reported that the ship was taking on water and listing to port less than 30 minutes prior to the EPIRB first being detected.

SummaryOfEvents:
Stranded after dragging anchor on the beach at Karasu, Turkey on 31/03/17 in heavy weather.
No injuries were reported. Sustained damage to the hull. Oil started to leak into the sea a month later. The wreck was recycled in situ in November 2017.

SOLASStatus: CAPTAIN D: Unknown/unspecified, JAN CARIBE: Unknown/unspecified
SummaryOfEvents: The ship sank after colliding with Jan Caribe whilst underway in the Rio Escondido near Mahogany in good weather. The ship sustained damage to the port side of the hull and took on water prior to capsizing and sinking. All passengers and crew were rescued by local ships prior to capsizing. One crew member sustained injuries and was taken to a local hospital for medical attention.

SummaryOfEvents: On 24 March 2017, ship's crew sounded the cargoholds bilges and found that Cargohold No. 1 was flooded with water. Upon inspection, Cargohold No.1 was found to have 3 cracks and the crew used leak stopper to stop the water flooding the cargohold but was unsuccessful. The ship ANA OCEAN with the rescued crew proceeded to its destination port Zhangjiagang, China, and ETA is 1 April 2017 night.

On 28 March 2017, while vessel transiting at Suez Canal en-route to Singapore, at about 1550Lt, Lat. 15-11.4N Long 041-49.8E, Chief Officer noted that 2nd.Engineer is missing. Chief Officer searched for missing 2nd.Engineer within accommodation area such as cabin, mess rooms, galley, alleyways of numerous decks, however, could not locate 2nd.Engineer. Chief Officer reported to Master. At 1600Lt activated the alarm, carried out crews searched for missing 2nd.Engineer. Master sent out Man Over Board messages through VHF,NAVTEX and Inmarsat-C. Distress Signal was sent out to MRCC for search assistance.

Location: South China Sea 40 miles E of Vung Tau
SummaryOfEvents: The ship sank after collision with Petrolimex 14 in the South China Sea 40 miles E of Vung Tau in good visibility. The ship sustained severe damage to the starboard side of the hull adjacent to no. 1 hatch cover and took on water prior to sinking. Two crew were rescued by Petrolimex 14. Vietnamese SAR ships and other ships effected the SAR operation. The submerged wreck was subsequently located by a Vietnamese navy research ship. The bodies of the 9 missing crew were later found by divers and brought ashore.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Total loss of the ship

Location: South China Sea 43 miles E of Vung Tau
SummaryOfEvents: The ship collided with Hai Thanh 26-BLC in the South China Sea 43 miles E of Vung Tau. No injuries or pollution were reported. The ship sustained a two metre gash in the starboard side of the hull near the waterline. Rescued two crew from Hai Thanh 26-BLC which subsequently sank, and assisted in the search for the remaining nine missing crew. Despite a brief search of localised areas of the vessel by his colleagues, he had not been located. 

The vessel conducted a full search of the vessel and returned to the geographical position corresponding to the time at which the person had last been sighted on the vessel. This was later supplemented by assistance from Egyptian naval vessels and an aircraft. 

The search carried on throughout the rest of the day and into the later evening. After sunset, the likelihood of sighting a person in the water became improbable and the vessel called off its search and resumed passage to Jeddah. 

The incident was reported to the relevant authorities as a man overboard (MoB) incident. 

The marine safety investigation recognised that during the course of the investigation several aspects of the vessel's Safety Management System had latent procedural shortcomings in relation to 3rd party contractors. It was determined that although these were not directly related to the events that took place resulting in the missing 3rd party contractor, identifying these within the report would benefit the Operators in addressing these shortcomings.

SummaryOfEvents:
On 08 March 2017 at about 0423 hours LT (UTC+8 hour), the Panamanian registered vessel MV “Global Vanguard” and another vessel MV “Thor Achiever”, a Singapore registered vessel, collided in the Singapore Strait, in approximate postion Lat 01° 26.55’N; Long 104° 29.1’E. Both vessels were heading West bound from South China Sea and about to enter the West bound TSS at the Eastern entrance of the Singapore Strait when they collided. The Master of the MV Global Vanguard was on the bridge and in command at the time of the collision.  

At 0345 hours, the vessel MV Thor Achiever, a bulk carrier, was some 1.5 nautical miles on the starboard quarter of the MV Global Vanguard. The MV Thor Achiever was doing a speed of about 13.5 knots and the MV Global Vanguard’s speed was 12.2 knots. They were heading to enter the Westbound lane of the TSS in the Singapore Strait. By 0400 hours it became apparent the MV Thor Achiever was an overtaking vessel. The two vessels were approaching close to each other in an overtaking situation. The MV Thor Achiever was on the starboard quarter of the MV Global Vanguard and closing in to overtake the MV Global Vanguard on her port side and 0.4 nautical mile away. At 0415 hours the MV Thor Achiever was abeam of MV Global Vanguard about 0.4 nautical mile away. And at 0420 hours, MV Thor Achiever overtook the MV Global Vanguard and was slightly forward of the beam of the MV Global Vanguard. Soon after this time, the MV Thor Achiever appeared to suddenly altered course to port. This put the two vessels in a collision course. The MV Global Vanguard had no room to manuoever to port as they were other vessels in the vicinity. A collision situation was imminent. 

At about 0423 hours, three minutes later, the two vessels collided. At the time of collision the weather was fine and the visibility was good and clear with light breeze. The speed of the MV Global Vanguard was about 10.8 knots. The other vessel MV Thor Achiever’s speed was also about 10.8.knots. On board the MV Global Vanguard, the radars were in operation and in working order. The impact of the collision caused damage to MV Global Vanguard starboard side in way of No.1 Hatch and breached the starboard cargo bilges with ingress of water. The vessel also sustained damage to the shell plating on her starboard quarter in way of starboard No. 1 & 2 oil waste tanks. However, There was no leakeage of oil and hence no oil pollution. 

There was no information as to any damage to MV Thor Achiever. The MV Global Vanguard proceeded to a safe anchorages after the accident as instructed by the VTIS centre. 

Soon after the collision the MV Global Vanguard tried to call the  MV Thor Achiever on the VHF Channels 16 and 10 but there was no response.

At about 0530 on 9 February 2017, the passenger cruise ship L’Austral began its entry to Milford Sound with an authorised harbour pilot on board. Because it was dark and there were no external visual navigation aids, the bridge team was using only the ship’s electronic navigation systems to conduct the pilotage.

As the ship was making a turn off Dale Point, the pilot lost awareness of exactly where the ship was, the direction in which it was heading and the effects of the wind and tide on the ship.

The L’Austral deviated well off the planned track and struck a stony bank near the shoreline of Milford Sound. The ship suffered scraping and indentation of the hull on its starboard side, but the hull was not breached and nobody on board was injured.

The Transport Accident Investigation Commission (Commission) found that the ship’s crew on the bridge noticed the ship was off its planned track, but did not bring this to the pilot’s attention until it was too late to avert the grounding.

The Commission found that the bridge team were not making full use of the ship’s electronic navigation systems to ensure that the ship stayed on track.

The Commission identified three safety issues:
- the primary means for navigation on board the L’Austral, the electronic chart display and information system, was not being used to its full potential as a tool for planning and monitoring the ship’s passage, and the crew were not fully conversant with its safety features
- the standard of bridge resource management on board the L’Austral during the Milford Sound pilotage did not meet good industry practice
- conducting ‘blind pilotage’ with large ships in confined waters represented risks that had not been fully considered by Environment Southland, the regional authority that regulates maritime activity in the area.

The Commission repeated two previous recommendations to the ship’s operator (Compagnie des Iles du Ponant) and made one new recommendation to Environment Southland to address the safety issues.

The Commission had previously found that poor bridge resource management under pilotage was a factor contributing to accidents involving two other ships in New Zealand. Their two reports had made several recommendations aimed at improving the standard of pilotage and making the transition of the pilot into the ship’s bridge team seamless.

Key lessons arising from this inquiry were:
- a ship’s passage plan is more than just the planned track for the ship to follow. Every part of a ship’s voyage must be planned and all members of the bridge team be fully familiar with and agree to the plan. This is a cornerstone of good bridge resource management
- good bridge resource management relies on a culture where challenge is welcomed and responded to, regardless of rank, personality or nationality
- an electronic chart display and information system is a valuable aid to navigation. However, mariners need to fully understand and be familiar with all aspects of the system, particularly when using it for blind pilotage.

This serious incident occurred on 29 January 2017, when the 140 m geared bulk carrier was anchored in Keppel Bay, Queensland. While conducting painting and routine touch-up work in the cargo holds, deck crewmembers were using a mobile scaffold tower. As the scaffold tower was moved with two unsecured crewmembers still on the upper tiers, it became unbalanced and toppled forward onto the deck.  

The ATSB found that by remaining on the unsecured scaffold tower in preparation for repositioning, contrary to established procedures, the two crewmembers had rendered it top-heavy and unstable. Consequently, when moved, it toppled and fell. Additionally, neither crewmember on the scaffold tower utilised the required safety harness and associated safety lines which would have prevented them falling when climbing or working on the tower. 

This investigation report highlights the importance of adhering to procedures that assure safety as well as the value of effective supervision. Ship owners, operators and crewmembers are reminded to plan and undertake risk assessments for assigned tasks in order to identify any shortcomings in procedures and required risk-mitigation measures.

The cargo vessel Fisktrans loaded a fish product in Lødingen for unloading in Bodø on 25 January 2017. Around midnight they departed Lødingen and sailed southward in Vestfjorden. The weather was bad with rain and strong winds from South-southwest. They got the wind and sea on the starboard side and the skipper decided to slow down the speed a little to adjust to the weather.
At about 0500 am the "no rudder response" alarm sounded. The crew perceived from the rudder indicator that the rudder had locked up on 15º starboard and they implemented several measures to correct this. It has not been possible for the Accident Investigation Board Norway (AIBN) to determine why the rudder ceased to work.
AIBN considers that the skipper, together with the crew, and in dialogue with the Rescue Coordination Center (RCC), implemented the necessary measures after they perceived that the rudder had locked. The skipper started the side-thrusters forward and aft in order to try to keep the bow up against the weather, but the wind and the sea was too strong. Due to the bad weather conditions, the problem with the rudder lead the vessel to drift towards land and they slowly approached a critical situation.
At about 0700 am a helicopter rescued the crew of six. None of the crew was hurt in connection with the accident and the rescue operation.
After the crew was rescued, the vessel drifted uncontrollably by wind and sea, passing through an area of shallow waters with rocks, landslides and slopes. At 1117 am Fisktrans shipwrecked outside Brennvika. It is uncertain whether the massive damages in the hull, below the intact waterline, occurred because of the collision with the seabed or when it passed through the area of shallow waters with rocks, landslides and slopes.
The AIBN does not promote any safety recommendations in connection with this investigation.

SummaryOfEvents:

The investigation revealed gaps in navigation relating to bridge resource management and identified issues pertaining to appropriate bridge team composition when navigating in areas of higher traffic density and compliance with COLREGs.

On 22 January 2017, at about 0010, cargo deck crane no. 1, fitted on board the Maltese registered bulk carrier Trapezitza, experienced a catastrophic failure during cargo operations in the port of Damietta, Egypt.

Consequently, the cargo deck crane s combined unit and jib parted from the pedestal base and fell on the jetty, coming in contact with the cargo hold hatch cover and main deck railings.

Discharging operations were suspended and the managers arranged for the cargo to be discharged by shore cranes. The remaining cranes on board were also thoroughly inspected.

The safety investigation concluded that the immediate cause of the accident was the failure of the slewing ring bearing, as a result of excessive wear and tear in the outer ring.  This led to spalling of the ball bearings and raceways, which was augmented by metal particle contaminated grease.

SummaryOfEvents:
On or about 1740H of 16 January 2017, M/V VIRGINIA, a 47 year old, 215.41 GT wooden hulled General Cargo ship, loaded with an assortment of Break Bulk Cargoes, departed Delpan Wharf, Manila bound for Roxas, Palawan manned by eleven (11) crew members. Roughly seven hours after departure, while transiting between the waters of El Fraile and Caballo Island, M/V VIRGINIA was gutted by fire and subsequently sank,1.5 NM South West of Corregidor Island, Bataan.  Accordingly, the fire was initially detected coming from the purser’s cabin which allegedly emanated from the roof of the bridge where several Styrofoam containers and plastic drums were stowed.

According to the survivors, the fire continued unabated until the roof collapsed which prompted the fire to cascade downwards to the ship’s upper deck.  The crew mustered and continued to fight the fire.  However, due to thick smoke and rapid expanding flames, the crew failed to extinguish the fire.  The blaze quickly spread on the ship’s superstructure and to all her cargo spaces within a short period of time.  Due to the risk of being trapped, the Master decided to give the order to abandon ship and accepted consequences as a loss event.

Seven crew members were rescued including the Master of the ship; nonetheless, four (4) crew members were reported missing including one oiler who was allegedly confirmed to have perished due to fatigue and hypothermia.  The accident resulted to the total loss of the ship, four missing crew and dumping of approximately 6,000 liters of marine diesel fuel in the environment.

On 7 January 2017 L’Austral sailed from Lyttelton with 200 passengers and 156 crew on board, bound for the Snares Islands, south of New Zealand. 
L’Austral arrived off the Snares Islands early on the morning of 9 January 2017.  The passengers spent the morning making shoreline excursions in rigid-hulled inflatable boats, observing the wildlife.  That afternoon the weather became unsuitable for small-boat excursions, so L’Austral rendezvoused with the boats in the sheltered water to the south of the islands to take them back on board. 
While the master was focused on manoeuvring the ship to facilitate the safe recovery of the rigid-hulled inflatable boats, the ship drifted into a 300-metre unauthorised zone, where it contacted an uncharted rock.  The rock pierced the hull in an empty void tank, which flooded with water.  The damaged compartment had little effect on the ship’s stability, and the ship was able to continue to another sub-Antarctic island before returning to New Zealand for temporary repairs.  Nobody was injured. 
The Transport Accident Investigation Commission (Commission) found that L’Austral inadvertently entered the 300-metre unauthorised zone, which the ship was not permitted to enter and in which the charts noted the existence of overfalls, eddies and breakers. 
The uncharted rock was in an area that the Commission considers was not suitable for the safe navigation of ships the size of L’Austral.

Location: South China Seas (en-route from Taiwan to Singapore)
InitialEvent: Fall from height of more than 12m
SummaryOfEvents:
On 6 January 2017, the Ocean Glory in ballast condition departed Kaohsiung, Taiwan, China for Singapore before proceeding to its next loading port in Australia. At Singapore, the vessel was expected to take bunkers while carrying out some repairs.

On 7 January 2017, while en-route from Taiwan, China to Singapore, the vessel’s crew commenced washing of cargo holds with seawater, in preparation for carriage of grain cargo. The last cargo carried onboard was limestone in bulk. No.1 and No.2 cargo holds were washed without any incident.

On 8 January 2017, at about 0900H, the vessel’s crew began to clean No.3 cargo hold with seawater.

At about 1000H, after the upper aft section of No.3 cargo hold had been washed, the Able-Bodied Seaman detached his safety harness lifeline from the securing point on the platform, and began his climb up the vertical ladder. During this climb, as he was nearing the top of the ladder, he fell backward and down from a height of about 12 metres (m) to the bottom of the cargo hold and suffered multiple injuries.

The Master deviated his vessel’s passage to Qui Nhon in Vietnam, the nearest port, for the injured seaman to seek medical treatment. However, the seaman succumbed to his injuries about seven hours after the occurrence.

The TSIB classified the occurrence as a Very Serious Marine Casualty and launched an investigation.

The investigation identified that the seaman lost his grip of the vertical ladder while climbing. His safety harness was not connected to any strong point or fall arresting device. 

The seaman’s inability to grip the vertical ladder could have been due to the following:

• Wet cargo hold
• Wet gloves worn by the seaman
• Slippery surface as a result of the seawater wash
• Exertion from his climb up the vertical ladder immediately after some physical activities

Ship was leaving Rotterdam under pilotage when it came into contact with the Willemsbrug Bridge.
Causes were found to be a wrong declaration of the air draft in the wheel house and the pilot ignoring the master's concerns that there was insufficient room for the ship to pass safely under the bridge.

Location: North Atlantic Ocean 97 miles SW of the Faroe Islands
SummaryOfEvents:
The ship caught fire in storage compartment in forecastle whilst fishing in the North Atlantic Ocean 97 miles SW of the Faroe Islands in good weather.
Initial attempts by crew to extinguish the fire were unsuccessful. All 10 crew were rescued and taken to Torshavn, Faroe Islands for medical checks. No injuries were reported. Patrol boats attended the scene. The blaze was extinguished by the following day and taken in tow to Skaala, Faroe Islands for inspection. Sustained severe damage to the superstructure. Subsequently sold for recycling.

On 6th. January 2017, Ro – Ro Passenger Ship  Amanna suffered a major fire in the {A/ES. Room} at Berth of Osman Digna port, when the ship was  Ready to sail.
There were no injurie, but the (A/E.No.1) was significantly damaged .and electric cables.

C/E. Stopped all running A/Es. and main engines.(Black out ).
Engine crew started to extinguish fire .same time emergency generator started but they failed to put of the fire.
C/E. ordered all fire dampers, ventilators, quick closing valves and water tight doors, to be closed.

The Zahro Express ferry was carrying more than 230 people to the tourist destination of Pulau Tidung island, a resort some 27 nautical miles from the capital, Jakarta.  It burst into flames about 0.8 nautical miles from Muara Angke port in Jakarta, about fifteen minutes after the ferry set sail. Many people on board jumped into the sea, 194 people were rescued and 23 killed while divers were deployed to search for 17 missing passengers. . The remains of the ferry were towed back to Jakarta, where images showed the devastation caused by the blaze.
